Pleasant and useful now to know that these two are who they are, and related to us, in this next Century, in the way we see! I will freely apply to you again, if I need the like service. Meanwhile, when you write again, please give me the full Titles &c of those two Books (Dictionaries, or whatever they are) which you have drawn from;Browning gave the titles, 23 Jan., as “Dictionnaire de la Noblesse. Vol 4 Paris 1772” (François A. Aubert de la Chesnaye Des Bois, Dictionnaire de la Noblesse, 15 vols. [Paris, 1770–86]) and “Dictionnaire Généalogique, Héraldique, Chronologique et Historique. Vol. 3. Paris, 1757” (François A. Aubert de la Chesnaye Des Bois, Dictionnaire Généalogique, Héraldique, Chronologique et Historique, 7 vols. [Paris, 1757–65]). He also gave a third title, ” ‘Histoire généalogique et héraldique des Pairs de France,’ &c. Vol. 8. Paris, 1827” (see 30:132TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855). their Price especially, and where they can be had on sale: the London Library, if one’s own is too poor, ought to have a Copy of such Books.

I have also, in obedience to your generous order, written to Chapman for a Copy of Men and Women;Two vols., pbd. Nov. 1855. Browning wrote, 23 Jan.: “I was without the courage to send you the book—fearing the fate of Talleyrand’s Grandfather. … But that fear seems stupid on reflection—for you have written, beside the word now [see 30:133TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855], many words once on a time—the best I ever got for my pains.” hope to have it in a day or so farther; and will certainly read it with attention,—as I may well do; as indeed I perceive all manner of intelligent people are diligently doing. Such is the fact; beyond doubt, in this bottomless, shoreless, vilely fermenting mud-lake and general reservoir of Human Nonsenses, which is called the “Literary Public,” I can very well see you too have got an understanding audience scattered up and down; and it may be a satisfaction to reflect on that, in certain moods. “The great soul of this world,” in spite of its outer nonsenses, “is just.”Cf. Josiah Conder, “The Lord Is King,” st. 5, and see Works 15:146. One has occasion to remember that, now and then; and the higher mount the floods of nonsense, the fact becomes the more sternly sacred to one. Courage, Courage! Brutal Delirium only seems to be the King of this world; and is not in reality,—much as he bothers poor fellows, from time to time.

We were at a Country House in Hampshire, during Christmas time; and the entertainment of two evenings, much the best two that turned up, was reading (superlatively well-done) out of Browning’s Men and Women. The Old Corregidor (“How it appears to a Contemporary”), that Devils “Bishop and Gigadibs“:For “Old Corregidor,” see “How It Strikes a Contemporary,” line 90; for “Gigadibs,” see “Bishop Bloughram’s Apology,” line 13; both Men and Women. we sat (being intelligent creatures, all) in rapt attention, with
the little ruffles of assent (chiefly nasal, laughter being prohibited as it were), and understood everything,—as indeed the melodious clear Voice (Lady Ashburton’s) had beforehand taken care to do. Two Evenings, the best two we had; and good hopes there were of more, had not unluckily our reading genius “Caught cold,” and left us eclipsed thenceforth. Her Ladyship has one of the finest strong Lady-voices and also one of finest intellects capable of comprehending big and little; reads, therefore, without being the least of “a reader,” better than any person I have heard.John Tyndall recalled: “Lady Ashburton, with fine voice and expression, read for us one of Browning’s poems. It was obvious from his ejaculatory remarks that Carlyle enjoyed and admired Browning” (Wilson, Carlyle 5:207). Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828–82; ODNB), Pre-Raphaelite poet and painter, wrote to Browning, 6 Feb., that a friend had recently had a talk with TC about Browning, in which TC said that Lady Ashburton’s reading of “How It Strikes a Contemporary” “went near to make him give up his resolution against reading poetry” (A. A. Adrian, “The Browning-Rossetti Friendship,” PMLA 73 [1958]: 542).

You do me far too much honour, dear Browning, when you ask my poor counsel and judgement about these things. I have never been in doubt about the noble spiritual outfit I discerned in you from our first acquaintance, many years back now; and my faith still is, you have got a great deal to tell your poor fellow creatures contemporary and future. But as to the How? this I more and more see to be an infinitely complex question; dependent on individualities, idiosyncrasies; not to be judged by the bystander (who never will completely understand the question): on this what can I say, or what is the use of my saying at this stage? However, you are so loyal, you shall know what my impressions are, by and by.— I wish you lived here, Mrs B. and you, on this side of the sea! Meanwhile, write now & then; and all good be ever with you T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 27 Jan. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I shall not get to you on Monday Evg after all; we seem destined never to get done with this paltry business!The Lowe subscription; see TC to JF, 2 Jan.

The faithless Actuary Brydges, for the second time, does not keep his promise: he was to send me, or bring me, on Friday Evg last, his answers to my three simple questions, that I might be ready for you next night (which was then the state of our bargain): on Friday Evg nothing came; yesterday, still more to my surprise, nothing came;—nor has anything today. And, except at his Office (presumably) before 4 o’clock,—all shut today,—I know not where to find the faithless Brydges!—— It is probable he will come or send
tomorrow; but I dare not, on that basis, engage. Let the thing lie over till he do come or send, and fairly resolve me on those preliminary points?
I will write again tomorrow; and hope to be able to appoint Tuesday or Wednesday. “May the Lord put an end unto all cruel wars,

“And send peace and contentment to all British tars!”—as I have heard lame sailors hoarsely sing in my young days.The last two lines of “Second of August,” written to stimulate public generosity for seamen wounded in Nelson’s failed attack on the French invasion fleet at Boulogne, 1801 (see Oxford Book of Sea Songs [Oxford, 1986] 171); see 8:295TC to JCA, 5 Feb. 1836, where unidentified. Alas, alas!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: I had an Answer from Browning (excellently successful), who mentions you and your promotionTo sec. of the Lunacy Commission, see TC to JF, 2 Jan. Browning wrote, 23 Jan.: “We were rejoicing the other evening over Forster’s good fortune,—from him, I have not heard.” with the fit loyalty and affection—

div3.sourceNote: TC-ES, 28 Jan. Pbd: G. Strachey, “Carlyle and the ‘Rose-Goddess,’ ” Nineteenth Century 32 (Sept. 1892): 485. Edward Strachey (1812–1901; ODNB; see TC to ES, 2 June 1838, TC to ES, 6 Aug. 1850, and TC to JAC, 23 April 1855).
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD STRACHEY

docBody.p: No book I ever undertook has been such a misery to me, from causes extrinsic and intrinsic, as this of Frederick the Great; thoughtlessly gone into, and in which I am still sunk overhead, uncertain yet whether I shall ever get out of it alive. Innumerable things are proven in that enterprise; this, which is worst of all, that I have literally no motive to proceed, except the conscientious reluctance to be quite beaten; that, in fact, I have little real love for Frederick, and for his century, and its works and ways, contemptuous abhorrence rather than love.

It will give me real pleasure to see you again, which by some happy chance I hope to do before long. I expect to be steady here, sunk in my sad Brandenburg element of ‘barren sand’Untraced. for many months to come.

closer.salute: I am always, with many affectionate regards and recollections,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC’s draft[TC]-Ed. of the Times[EOT], [ca. 28 Jan.]. MS: FC. TC wrote his draft on the blank pages of William Bridges’s note on headed notepaper, Mitre General Life Assurance, 23 Pall Mall, 25 Jan. TC wrote the draft sometime after TC to JF, 27 Jan., when he had not yet received Bridges’s note. The draft is included here as it has several differences from the final version that was pbd. in the Times, 11 Feb. (see TC, CD, and JF[TCCDJF] to Ed. of the Times[EOT], 8 Feb.).
div3.head: TC TO EDITOR OF THE TIMES

docBody.p: Sir,—On behalf [For behoof]Where TC has written words above the line, they are placed between square brackets in the text. of such of your readers as took interest in the Subscription for Saml Johnson’s Goddaughter the aged Miss Lowe and her Sister; whh was set on foot in Novr last, will you permit us to announce that the same is about to close.

The sum raised is still [only] considerably under £300: but on the other hand, the price of such a [the proposed] Life Annuity proves cheaper than we anticipated; and in addition to this, there has a lucky chance come to help us a little. Mauritius Lowe, Miss Lowe’s father, is now discovered to have been the benevolent Painter by whom Turner, at that time a barber’s boy, was first recognised, befriended, and saved to Art: in return for which fine action, an ardent and renowned admirer of TurnerJ. M. W. Turner (1775–1851; ODNB); Ruskin was his executor. See also 30:107TC to RMM, 6 Nov. 1855. (whose name we do not indicate farther) [everyone guesses, rightly, to be Mr Ruskin] decides to gratify himself by bestowing henceforth £5 annually on the Misses Lowe, and permits us to publish such his resolution, if that can make it more binding. So that, on the whole, there is now as good as an “addal Annuity of £30,” £30, which was our minimum limit, secured for these aged ladies; and thus by one means and another, our small problem can be considered as done.

One fact must not be omitted: there has been no soliciting, nor shadow of such, anywhere used in this matter. The sum gathered has altogether fallen voluntarily, like the rain or the dew; as genuine gift of the feelings appealed to;—rather touching to see amid the huge expenditures (not all of them celestial, or like the dew on Gideon’s fleece)Cf. Judg. 6:37–40. of this our day!— We beg to thank very sincerely our fellow contributors; and dismiss the little transient assemblage with a kindly farewell.

The Subscriptn Books at Messrs Coutts’s Strand & at Messrs Grote and Prescott’s—Street, City, will continue open till (Wednesday the—?); after Wednesday they will be closed; and the net Amount will then promptly be invested in the form of Life Annuity for the Misses Lowe, we expect, in the
Mitre &c,William Bridges wrote, 25 Jan.: “The elder Miss Lowe is 77,—born 29 Sept. 1778. The younger 73, 20 Jan 1783 The £21 of Long Annuities would realize about £72 / Add——220 / £292 / For £300 the Mitre, whose rates are as liberal as is consistent with safety, would grant an Annuity to the two ladies & the survivor, of £42. // I enclose a form of Annuity proposal in case the matter should be proceeded with.”—and so soon as that operation is complete, the List of Subscribers will be published in The Times.

closer.salute: We have the honour to be, Sir, &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 31 Jan. Addr: Willesden House / Willesden. MS: letter: NLS 552.118; envelope: NLS 552.117. Hitherto unpbd. Neuberg wrote several notes on the back of TC’s letter.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Correspondence of Prince Karl and Count Seckendorf (about that Wemdingen business) 1744 (abt May and afterwards).TC wrote these enquiries to Neuberg and then began the letter beneath. Prince Karl Alexander of Lorraine (1712–1780), commander of Maria Theresa of Austria’s army. Friedrich Heinrich (1673–1763), count von Seckendorf, commander of Bavarian forces; see 29:336TC to JN, 19 June 1855. The correspondence of Prince Karl and Seckendorf is not mentioned in Frederick. For Wemdingen, see Works 15:443–44.

“Circular-Rescript” of Maria Theresa abt ditto, 13 May and 13 june 1744.See Works 15:444–48. Maria Theresa (1717–80), Holy Roman empress from 1745 and archduchess of Austria; see 29:160TC to LA, 4 Oct. 1854.— — In answer to which, is

“Circr Rescript” of 21 june with 6 appendices, by Kaiser (Karl VII).Charles VII (Karl Albrecht) (1697–1745), Holy Roman emperor, 1742–45. (In Sammlung der Staatsschriften nach Karl des 6ten Tode;Probably Sammlung einiger Staats-Schriften welche nach Ableben Kayser Carl des VI zum Vorschein gekommen (Frankfurt am Main, 1741–43).—which probably is not in the Museum; tho’ perhaps some Analogous Farrago may be? Faber Faber: Staatscanzeley [State Chancellery]Anton Faber, Europäische Staatskanzlei, 115 vols. (Nürnberg, 1697–1760). is another)

Do not bother too much abt that Seckendorf business, which in truth is worth little to me. I can turn it some way or other; and even do if you find nothing for me. The same about the Dictature.About compensation for Maria Theresa for loss of territory and the succession to the Holy Roman Empire; see Works 15:444–48. If you can find the date, well, and better than otherwise; but we must not grovel too much in that mud element,—mass it all up into the vague in case of need.

I shd like better (if you have found the Du Châtelet Book)Lettres inédites de Madame la marquise Du Châtelet et Supplément à la correspondance de Voltaire avec le roi de Prusse (Paris, 1818), mentioned in Neuberg’s notes written on the back of the letter. that you took some Abstract for me (in yr usual dextrous way, retaining bits of the original) of Madame’sGabrielle Emilie (1706–49), marquise du Châtelet; see 29:6TC to EM, 5 Jan. 1854. jealous Letters, or Letter to Voltaire, while he was with Fredk on visit at Wilhelmina’s, Septr (13–18?) 1743.See Works 15:452–62. This I cannot quite dispense with, some time or other.—The Book (lost) is ordered for me again; but one knows not when it will come.
My fire stands out pretty fairly even agt this sunless frost.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JWP], 31 Jan. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [J. W. PARKER]

docBody.p: Please read the inclosed Note, and then burn it.

This Mr Horrocks, whose Ms. you seem to be about receiving, is one of two or perhaps three English Brothers who usually reside at Weimar, and busy themselves with various speculative matters.See 27:2TC to JMA, 5 Jan. 1852, where unidentified; probably Capt. Charles Horrocks, author of Horace Grantham; or, the Neglected Son, 3 vols. (1852); and A Brief Career; or, The Jew’s Daughter, 3 vols. (1854); and possibly James D. Horrocks, author of Zeno, a Tale of the Italian War, and other Poems. To which are added Translations from Modern German Poetry, or John Horrocks, author of Die Kunst der Fliegenfischerei auf Forellen und Aschen in Deutschland und Oesterreich. … Mit einem Titelkupfer und Tafeln mit Abbildingen der ausgesuchtesten kunstlichen Fliegen (Weimar, 1874). No article by any Horrocks appeared in Fraser’s. In a comment to the CLO Feedback Page submitted on 8 Aug. 2009, Michael Demy-Geroe points out that the only Horrocks brothers to live in Weimar were John (1816–81), who lived there from 1842 until his death, and his twin brother, Capt. Charles (1816–81), who lived there 1846–56. This one, whom I remember to have seen once here (and that is all our direct acquaintance) appeared to me a sharp kind of young man, probably with considerable activity of intellect, perhaps with rather beyond the average of reading found among Magazine Contributors (perhaps also not, for how do I know?),—and to be of a brisk, decisive nature. For the rest, they are all perfectly respectable people, in every sense of that word.— This is all I can say.

I know not whether you will think his Ms. worth the careful examination he wants for it; but if you are not very busy, it might be worth while. I have no light to advise you, one way or the other; nor is any interest of mine (except as above) involved in the decision.
docBody.name: [no signature]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [1 Feb.]. MS: FC. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:211. Dated the Friday between William Bridges’s note, 25 Jan. (see TC to EOT, [ca. 28 Jan.]), and the final version of TC, CD, and JF[TCCDJF] to ed. of the Times[EOT], 8 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Many thanks, my industrious unwearied Forster! That will do capitally—and all is right in the end.

I have altered one word with the pen (alteration indispensable); two pencil suggestions are dubious, optional,—especially the 2d; whh I almost believe you will do well to cut out still?In FC there is a neat copy of TC’s draft letter to the Times,TC to EOT, [ca. 28 Jan.], about the Lowe appeal, but there are no alterations by TC.—

Long life to you, dear F—and recommend me to Dickens; and thank him a hundred times for “The Circumlocution Office”;In Little Dorrit, bk. 1, chap. 10, “Containing the whole Science of Government,” just pbd., and which TC must have read immediately. whh is priceless after its sort! We have laughed loud and long over it here; and laughter is by no means the supreme result in it.—Oh Heaven
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LA], 2 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: It surely cannot be unlawful to beg for a word of clear news from you in these distressing circumstances. I am grieved to the heart to think of your anxieties, confusions, and of poor Lord An’s painful time;With his gout. and I do not even know whether you are still at Bornemouth or distinctly how or where you are! This is surely beyond what the Law, with its biggest wig, can prescribe. One little word of clear history, I beg in pity from you.

Of a truth I do not think too seldom of you, whatever I may do, tho’ I write nothing! The truth is, I am all dark as the winter-solstice in Spitzbergen;The main island in the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard in the Arctic Ocean. and do not afflict you with my Night Thoughts till the morning dawnCf. the anon. religious poem, ” ‘Night Thoughts’ Repeated at Dawn” (1853). again. As surely it will and must?— To add to all, I am a good way below average in health;—sad dinner at Lord Goderich’sOn 28 Jan. TC noted “(29 jany; dining at Ld Goderich’s last night: alas, alas!)—Not the least likelihood of finishing Voltaire’s business in this way. Indeed I feel as if completely in a cleft stick at this point of my progress in it, and must stop)” (MS: NLS 552.117). (and nothing but Spedding,James. Venables,
Brookfield &c; a mere rechauffée [reheated dish], with mournful reminiscence even of the hot state of that article!) has quite spoiled me all this week; and instead of being better (as I counted that I was, and perhaps really am, poor foolish soul!) I am sorrowfully worse. “Serve him right!” that is what the bystander may well say; and what I myself say.

One sad consolation is, I do not quit work: I must not, or I should go mad! At a snail’s pace (sometimes, alas, at a crab’s, the wrong way), I keep puddling along, whether dead or alive: some day I shall get delivered; and then—perhaps all things will be better!
One word, dear Lady,—and as many merciful thoughts as your kind heart can spare, the noble goodness of which I will not doubt of, whatever else I may fall to doubting.

The “extremity of haste,”Thomas De Quincey, “The English Mail-Coach,” The Collected Writings of Thomas De Quincey, ed. David Masson (Edinburgh, 1890) 13:321. that too is my category at present. Seldom did son of Adam write on such terms altogether.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-DD, 2 Feb. Pbd: David Davidson, Memories of a Long Life (Edinburgh, 1890) 301–2.
div3.head: JWC TO DAVID DAVIDSON

docBody.p:
My Dear Friend,—I made sure of seeing you before your departure from London, but you slipt away like that most provoking of all things, “a knotless thread;”See Burns, “My Tocher’s the Jewel,” line 15. and I was feeling to have “lost you quite.” “Not so fast!” (my gracious, were you ever “at the sea-bathing” in North Berwick?Town, East Lothian, 22 mi. E of Edinburgh. and do you remember an idiot that used to shuffle about there saying, “Not so fast!” I have not thought of him these five-and-thirty years before! and I could paint his picture at this moment, but it is not necessary). You have not forgotten us—or even forgotten “your promise,” and I call that very nice of you—being a man! Dear darling old BettyBraid; see 2:306JBW to EA, 8 March 1823, and 28:37428:biographical note. will be delighted to see you! it will be next best to seeing myself, and I should say you, with your memories of old things, will enjoy seeing her, and hearing her; and so the doctrine of “virtue ever its own reward”John Gay, “Epistle to Methuen,” line 39; also coterie speech; see 25:187–88JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1850. will for once at least hold good! The address is Mrs. Braid, 5 West Adam Street, in the George’s Square region it is. It would be a pleasure to visit you, and make acquaintance with your wife;Margaret Davidson. and decidedly I for
one, will not be in Scotland without inquiring how you are situated, and going to spend a day or two with you, “if convenient.” But Mr. C. has such a physical horror of travelling, and of any change, even for the better, in his arrangements, that our journeys are few and far between. It has become through a long course of years, a part of our life, like any other, to spend a month every winter at Lord Ashburton’s in Hampshire, and that one visit Mr. C. thinks quite a sufficient year’s visiting for both himself and me, in which notion I do not always agree with him. But “anything for a quiet life,”Proverbial, and the title of a play by Thomas Middleton and John Webster, pbd. 1662. as I daresay your wife says too sometimes. However, neither Mr. C. nor I have given up the idea of seeing old Scotland again, and I will keep the other idea (of visiting you and your wife) as an integral part of it. For the rest, you will be interested to hear that within the last two weeks, I have made two involuntary attempts on my life; neither of which proved fatal! First during my stay at the Grange, the house Dr. (the Ashburtons keep a Dr. all to themselves, a questionable luxury I think) ordered me an embrocation for my throat, and I DRANK it every drop!See JWC’s Journal, 30:232JWC’s Journal, 24 March 1856. The doctor was probably James Rouse, rather than Charles Locock (1799–1875; ODNB), whom Lady Ashburton consulted in London; see 23:119–20TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1848. supposing that England expected me!“England expects every man to do his duty,” Lord Nelson’s phrase before the battle of Trafalgar, 1805. A revolution of three days in my “interior” (as Mr. Carlyle calls it) was the unexpectedly unimportant result of this mistake. Since my return, in taking a flying leap in the dark (!) I struck myself a violent blow on the right side which was supposed to have fractured it; but as it was only sprained and bruised, I am now recovering, and won’t if I can remember it take flying leaps in the dark again; at least not till I return to Jeanie Welsh in some other planet. God bless you—my affection to Betty; and look me up again before long, will you?—Sincerely yours,
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG[AGI], 3 Feb. Pbd.: Gilchrist 46–47; ellipses in original.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Beyond doubt you are one of the successfullest hunters up of Old Books now living; and one of the politest of obliging men! Once more I have to declare myself very much your debtor, and grateful to be helped,—in such a spirit, and also with such effect.

The BielefeldJacob Friedrich von Bielfeld, Lettres familières et autres (La Haye, 1763); Gilchrist sent TC the 2d edn., 2 vols. (Leide, 1767); see 28:87TC to JN, 23 March 1853. is quite a conquest; vainly tried, in all manner of ways, for four years past: it would have saved me, and will still save me, many missions (missions, since visits are really impossible for me) to that dismal labyrinth of a British Museum; nay I may get out of it what no missions or visits would ever have given. …

I find in that old book of military Pictures, something of costume to learn from; and at least three portraits I was interested in,—Prince de Ligne (Prince of Puppies, as I call him) for one. N.B. all his pamphlets about Frederick (indifferent all, but unique some of them) are under my hand already.Karl Josef Emmanuel, prince de Ligne (1735–1814), Belgian military officer and writer; his memories of Frederick in Mémoires et mélanges historiques et littéraires, 6 vols. (Paris, 1827–29), see Works 19:255–65.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 4 Feb. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I hope you are not unwell,—that did not strike me till this moment! The fact is, Brydges came hither yesterday, seemingly desirous to know about the Miss-Lowe affair; and I could only say, Wait, and we will give you an appointment to meet, one of these days, and settle it all.— The old Dame herself wrote to me a while ago; and I answered, You shall have your Papers (Life Annuity Papers all signed and complete), I hope, “in three weeks.” By Brydges’s mistake and one cause and another,—I lament to perceive that this is now the third week, pretty much spent already!—

The truth is, dear Forster, I believe there is not intrinsically the least haste; and surely it is far from my part to hurry or bother you (so busy a man too) any farther than can be avoided, in a business you got into in the way you did! Take plenty of time, then:—predict to me what time I shall assign (or approximate time) to these old women, when I write again; and that is really all that is needful in the matter.

Alas, alas, I am pretty nearly choked this day with Brandenburg Dust-whirlwinds, spinning round me, wide as the Creation; and have hardly the least human sense left, till I get into the air again, and walk five miles. Pity me, pity me!— — You never sent the Oliver:Forster’s article. I must have it. Adieu, dear F.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [5 Feb.]. Addr: Willesden House / Willesden. PM: 5 Feb. 1856. MS: NLS 552.119. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—The man’s name (man of the 7-years War, I mean) is Decker;Karl von Decker (1784–1844), Die Schlachten und Hauptgefechte des siebenjährigen Krieges. Mit vorherrschender Bezugnahme auf den Gebrauch der Artillerie (Berlin, 1837). his translator into French is a Genl de Peretsdorf (not said exactly when, either of these); J. H. Le Bourg, French Artillery Captain, republishes with Notes &c in 1839 or ’40.Baron M. J. Didier Ravichio de Peretsdorf (1767–1844), Batailles et principaux combats de la guerre de Sept-ans, considérés principalement sous le rapport de l’emploi de l’artillerie avec les autres armes. … Revu, augmenté, accompagné d’observations et d’une notice sur le service de l’artillerie en campagne, par J. H. Le Bourg (Paris, 1839–40); see HCC under Karl von Decker.—

I have found the Dictature Papers, and all your Faber ware, in the Helden-Staats-&c!C. F. Hempel, Helden-, Staats- und Lebens-Geschichte des aller durchlauchtigsten und grossmächtigsten Fürsten und Herrns, Friedrichs des Andern (Frankfurt, 1758–66). TC wrote: “There are Ten thick and thin Half-volumes, and perhaps more. One of the most hideous imbroglios ever published under the name of Book,—without vestige of Index, and on paper that has no margin and cannot stand ink,—yet with many curious articles stuffed blindly into the awful belly of it, like jewels into a rag-sack, or into ten rag-sacks all in one; with far more authenticity than you could expect in such a case. Let us call it for brevity, Helden-Geschichte in future references” (Works 13:245). The date of the actual Dictature of that Protest was indisputably 23 Septr 1743 (? or the one you mark in your Paper); the Dictations of 3 july &c 1744 were for the purpose of explaining away the offence of that former one (No objection to Kaiser as Kaiser, only to the mode of election, Oh no! &c &c), Fredk being then about to invade Bohemia; and everything looking rather dangerous for Austria.See Works 15:445–52.
Do not mind Decker much; I believe I shall have to send for a Copy from Paris,—unless we can get some trace of it in the Old shops here.

What, in the way of Plan, Narrative or the like, does the King’s LibraryIn the British Museum Lib.; see 28:35TC to JN, 6 Feb. 1853. contain about Dettingen Battle, and Fontenoy?For Dettingen and Fontenoy, see 30:1930:13TC to JN, 28 July 1855.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LST], 7 Feb. MS: Strouse: Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: I need not say, “I would with much pleasure”; for that you already know, this long while past! But the sad fact is, I am so low and sickly I cannot go out to dine at all, in these weeks,—but have to sit mournful at home; up to the chin in old “Brandenburg rubbish,” unhappy that I am! I hope to get sight of you soon, some morning; and that you will drop a tear over me from those fine eyes.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

bibl.person: TC, CHARLES DICKENS, AND JOHN FORSTER

div3.sourceNote: TC, CD, and JF[TCCDJF]–Ed. of the Times[EOT], 8 Feb. Pbd: Times, 11 Feb.; DL 8:729. For TC’s draft of the letter, see TC’s draft[TC] to Ed. of the Times [EOT], [ca. 28 Jan.]. Text: DL; the letter has been untraced in the surviving Times, 11 Feb.; it may have been printed in an early edition. The date of publication is confirmed by William Nichol to TC, 11 Feb., where he refers to seeing the letter in the Times that day; see TC to JF, 12 Feb.
div3.head: TC, CHARLES DICKENS, AND JOHN FORSTER TO THE EDITOR OF THE TIMES

docBody.p: Sir,—On behalf of such of your readers as took interest in the subscription for Samuel Johnson’s goddaughter, the aged Miss Lowe, and her sister, which was set on foot in November last, will you permit us to announce that the same is about to close?

The sum raised is still but a little over 250l.; but, on the other hand, the price of such a life annuity as was proposed proves cheaper than we anticipated; and in addition to this there has been a lucky chance come to help us somewhat. Mauritius Lowe, Miss Lowe’s father, is now discovered to have been the benevolent painter by whom Turner, at that time a barber’s boy, was first recognized, befriended, and saved to art, in return for which fine action an ardent and renowned admirer of TurnerSee 30:107TC to RMM, 6 Nov. 1855. (whose name we need not indicate further) desires to gratify himself by bestowing henceforth 5l. annually on the Misses Lowe, and permits us to publish his resolution, if that can make it more binding. So that, on the whole, there is now as good as an “additional annuity of 30l.,” which was our minimum limit, secured for these aged ladies; and thus, by one means and another, our small problem can be considered as done.

One fact must not be omitted. There has been no soliciting, nor shadow of such, anywhere used in this matter. The sum gathered has altogether fallen
voluntarily. Very sincerely we beg to thank our fellow-contributors, and dismiss the little transient assemblage with a kindly farewell.

The subscription-books at Messrs. Coutts’s, Strand, and at Messrs. Grote and Prescott’s, 62, Threadneedle-street, City, will continue open until Wednesday, the 12th of March. After Wednesday, the 12th of March, they will be closed, and the net amount will then promptly be invested in the form of life annuity for the Misses Lowe,—we expect, in the Mitre Insurance-office, 23, Pall-mall,—and, so soon as that operation is complete, the list of subscribers will be published in The Times.

closer.salute: We have the honour to be, Sir,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.
Charles Dickens.
John Forster.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [8 Feb.]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries. MS: NLS 605.402. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:85–87 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I like to believe myself interesting to you and so I write to tell you about my side—or breast—(for I never know which to call it. the hurt being just where the rib joins the breast bone). I had made up my own mind—that after mustard blistering at it for four whole days (!) to subdue the inflamation; there was nothing more to be done— But Countess Pepoli (Elizabeth Fergus) and my chief Friend Geraldine Jewsbury made such long faces and prayed so hard I would “see a Surgeon“—that finally I saw a surgeon—and what was worse a surgeon “saw me“I, Johnny Peep, saw three sheep, / And then three sheep saw me, etc.” (A. Carlyle’s note).—” for I had to show him the pretty state into which I had reduced my skin with the mustard!— He laughed at my energetic manner of carrying out a prescription of mustard; and for the rest recommended—patience! which I “could not carry too far“—“These things took a long time” (I knew that as well as he) “and on the whole they were best let alone“—(I thought I knew that too)— He is a Brother in law of Sir Charles Bell’s the man, and Scotch—a Mr Shaw—Erasmus Darwin recommended him in preference to Brodie or CuttleSir Charles Bell (1774–1842; ODNB), surgeon and professor; Alexander Shaw (1804–90; ODNB), surgeon; Sir Benjamin Collins Brodie (1783–1862; ODNB; see 10:127TC to JAC, 18 July 1838); Cuttle unidentified. because “he wouldn’t flurry me, and
wouldn’t do anything merely for the sake of doing“—and that is just his virtue—for any complicated case I should never “see” him again; he looks so soft!— So I was glad to have got off without leeches! which I have a wild horror of being touched by! and also that I was not required to lay up—as without plenty of walking I cant sleep a bit—very little with it!
The pain is wearing off gradually and rapidly within the last few days—so that now I can lie in any position—indeed hardly feel it—and believe it to have been nothing but a simple sprain

Aren’t you glad we are to have peace? At least people who should know best believe in the peace. My own only two friends in the Crimean Army—Sir ColonThus in MS for “Colin.” Campbell and Colonel Sterling make no doubt but that Autumn will see them all home.

The people in the City, a Cabinet Minister told me yesterday, are getting as wild for war with America as they were for war with Russia! but there will be more words to that!In Dec. 1855, President Franklin Pierce (1804–69) asked Palmerston to recall his ambassador Sir John Fiennes Twisleton Crampton (1805–86; ODNB) for supporting the illegal recruitment of troops in the U.S. to be used in the Crimea; see also 30:255JWC’s Journal, 18 June. The American govt. also accused the British of violating the 1850 Clayton-Bulwer Act, assuring the neutrality of canals and railway routes in Central America. The British argued the act did not apply to protectorates acquired earlier in Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and on the Mosquito Coast. On 2 Feb., the Examiner reported the New York Herald’s view that unless Crampton was removed, affairs would assume “a more important and threatening aspect.” Clough wrote to a friend in the U.S., 16 Jan.: “Are you really going to fight with your ancestors about Costa Rica and the Clayton-Bulwer treaty? I hope not. … But Palmerston is a sad haggler, and may … go on making a fool of himself about his Mosquito protectorate until he gets a warning to be quiet” (Clough 2:516). The dispute was settled in 1860 when Britain yielded its claim on all territory but Belize.—

Your account of the Lann HallTynron, nr. Thornhill, Dumfriesshire; see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853. splendours amuses me very much— The idea of that quiet little sensible womanJanet Pringle, b. Hunter. having to pass her life beside a fountain in a conservatory! That sort of things are well enough when there is an immense Fortune and familiarity with beautiful and luxurious things to pass them perfectly into one’s life— But good heavens! Conservatories and fountains cant be brought to much glory with Dr Pringle’s resources—or be much in harmony when there, with Dr Pringle’s natural tastes—one would think! I dont feel these accessories, increase my desire to visit Mrs Pringle when I go to Scotland—if ever again— We had the Daughter of the Duke of Richmond at the Grange when I was there (Lady Bessbrough)See JWC to MW, [10 Jan.]. and when one wet day I asked her if she was going to walk in the conservatory? (it is the 36th part of a mile long) she said “Oh dear no! I put on strong shoes and take
an umbrella when it rains; and have a right long walk over the Downs— It is so much pleasanter.“— Mrs Pringle would have been much the better for a few days beside that real Lady—to learn simplicity
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Feb. MS: NLS 525.14. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I know not if you have much personal or other acquaintance with Saffi; but he seems very desirous to have your testimony,—and incloses this Letter to Jane, requesting me to plead with you for him.Count Aurelio Saffi had also written to JWC, 1 Jan., when he and Alexander Scott regretted that she and TC were away; he was in London “two or three weeks more” and had been “yesterday morning to breakfast with [F. D. Maurice] and the Misses Sterling at Queen Square.” I can only say you will be very safe in testifying anything you do know about him,—how (in conversation if not otherwise) you have found him well-informed abt &c &c.In John’s capacity as an Italianist and trans. of Dante’s Inferno (1849). I understand he has a good chance for this place (£150 a-year);The post is unidentified; he had been lecturing in Oxford since 1853. indeed I know not that there is any real competition.

We had the same wild wind-storm that visited you, on the same night; but it did not hurt us here, beyond howling and whewing about the chimney tops all night, if that could be called hurt.— Poor Alick’s Letter pleased me much, and was very affecting in the humour I was in.

Nothing can exceed the “mildness” (a too often very glarry heat) of the season just now: green buds all appearing on our lilac bushes, nay today I could actually have plucked you a kind of leaf from one. In great haste (for it is still forenoon), Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 12 Feb. Addr: 58. Lincoln’s Inn Fields. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Read these two Notes,—they will fill you with astonishment;—and keep them for future use!One was an anon. letter, 11 Feb.: “Sir, / Before investing the money you have collected for your Protegée in the Mitre Assurance Co please to make enquiries as to the stability of that society. … The Government give nearly as high a rate of annuity as any solid Life Office and are of course more secure than any. So, / I am, Sir, / a Great Admirer of your Genius and A Subscriber.” There were several anon. subscribers. The second note, marked “No 2” by TC, was from William Nichol, Liverpool, 11 Feb.: “In the Times of today I observe your letter … and I notice with some misgiving that it is proposed to insert this little stock with the Mitre Insurance Co.—”; Nichol had been asked to undertake the Liverpool agency for Mitre in May or June 1855, and “was offered an allowance of 27 ½% from the premiums in all policies” he gained for them; assuming that such a rate of commission was impossible, he refused: “I would not willingly see any of my friends trust to it,” warning TC of his “doubt as to the validity of the Security which you seem prepared to accept.” Nichol, a brother of John Pringle Nichol (1804–59; ODNB; see 11:195TC to JSM, 30 Sept. 1839), ended “you may just possibly recollect” his “various letters” about the Edinburgh Philosophical Inst., “a good many years ago” (in 1846; see 21:71TC to WN, 8 Oct. 1846); he had also invited TC to lecture in Edinburgh in 1838, when he had been a draftsman and printer there (see 10:120TC to JAC, 14 July 1838).
I find I know nothing, or almost nothing, practically of Brydges any more than of his Mitre Office: but it is pretty clear we must steer far to windward of that latter object!—

Ask now, and bid Dickens ask, What is the actually safe and proper Insurance Office (or what does my first Correspondt mean by Govt granting life annuites?), and in short whither we must go with our money on the 12th of March?The final investment was in a govt. annuity; see TC, CD, and JFTCCDJF to Ed. of the TimesT, 23 April.
I have got £10 more.— God grant a happy and a speedy end to all that bother to us all!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LA], 13 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Ashton 378.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Thanks, dear Lady, many thanks.— I fear “it is but talk,” however, that other point; and that you are not coming this week? One pair of eyes would be very blithe to see you. The sight of your handwriting, even that does me good, beyond what you imagine: I sink into such misgivings, scepticisms of the plainest truths, total (temporary) unbeliefs, in this dark element of mine. And I dare not write to you, dare not speak to you, scarcely think of you;—you must be a very dreadful creature? I myself am one! And if you do entirely forget me in this world, and I find that I have lost you, and the light of your countenance is turned away,Cf. Westminster Confession of Faith 18:4.—will it be good times with me, think you? I will try all extremities first; submit to the hardest laws Rhadamanthus and the
ancient or modern wigs can have made on that matter.I.e., rigorous justice as dispensed by Rhadamanthus (see 12:114TC to HMS, 17 April 1840) and “ancient or modern” judges. Or have you perhaps no thought of forgetting me,—not you! That is also perhaps the truth;—tho’ it remains always an incredible one to the impartial human mind. The human mind has much ado sometimes not to go mad, and give up the embroiled account altogether to insolvency in that way!—

I see nobody; I sit here, in grim task work, slaving what I can, day after day; run out in the afternoon late for a breath of air,—of wet fog as it oftener chances.Henry George Atkinson, a friend of Anna and Basil Montagu, had told Harriet Martineau that TC “looks so very picturesque in the street, with his brown beard, wideawake [see 26:237TC to LA, 22 Nov. 1851], and very individual dress” (15 Feb., Arbuckle 144). We are mud to the axles; this is the third day of muggy rain or slumberous Scotch-mist: gutta percha is valuable on the feet. At night I sit reading Jomini (his Napoleon affairs, this time),A. H. de Jomini; either Vie politique et militaire de Napoléon, racontée par lui-même, 2 vols. (Paris, 1827), or vol. 3 of Traité des grandes opérations militaires, contenant l’histoire critique des campagnes de Frédéric II, comparées à celles de l’Empereur Napoléon, avec un recueil des principes généraux de l’art de guerre, 8 vols. (Paris, 1811–16). who is a nearly intolerable puppy,—next to nothing in that head, with such a lot of plumages and cockade-work upon it.— — Will you tell Lord Ashburton to bid MasonLord Ashburton’s servant; he later committed suicide. bring me up the Barbier (of Louis XV),E. J. F. Barbier, Journal historique et anecdotique du règne de Louis XV; publié pour la société de l’histoire de France, 4 vols. (Paris, 1847–56). after all, when he comes and you. The Book will help me to a date now and then; and be worth something, even these volumes of it, if you are doing nothing with them.

I find Lady Sandwich out the last two times; well, and I suppose busy with her new House.She moved from 31 South St., Grosvenor Sq., to 46 Grosvenor Sq. in March. Jane was there along with her one day: a spacious pleasant house, Jane reports.— On Sunday, pausing in a long solitary walk, I found the Twisleton PetiteEllen Twisleton. in her place, Twn gone out, and VaughanHenry Halford Vaughan (1811–85; ODNB; see 29:36129:biographical note). waiting for him. Witty talk on one side, grim do on the other: well enough,—only one thinks it might be as well to be dead (and one’s work done), in certain moods of mind, in a world of this nature! Yet these are truly among the best people I know. “Perfect Blockhead” (who I find is truly a distinguished scientific character of his sort) was lecturing the other night, “Fallacy of Perpetual Motion,” or some melancholy matter of that sort; Jane (as the Opposition party) meant to go, but did not; I still less.W. R. Grove’s “Inferences from the Negation of Perpetual Motion” was at the Royal Inst., 25 Jan.; JWC had liked him at the Grange. What is “perpetual motion” to me; who have uneasy shoes, in all senses of the word, and no prayer so deep as that for rest?

Oh my Lady, I hope you will come, after all; and that you will have consideration for my heavy case,—swimming thro’ Chaos (Prussian and other) in these hapless circumstances;—and in fact be good to me, with that noble heart of yours, and not bad according to my merits. I have, on the whole, not many things now left that are lovely to me in this world.

The good old BearEdward Ellice. came down on Sunday, but we were both out. I keep to windward strictly of all Parliamentary or “Circumlocution Office”As in Dickens, Little Dorrit. jargons, having nonsense enough of my own to manage. I kiss your hands, noblest Being; and am ever
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, [mid-Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Dated very tentatively in relation to the Carlyles’ visit (17 Dec. 1855 to 14 Jan. 1856) to the Grange, where they may have seen Arthur Russell. It could be dated later. In 1862, he was to borrow one of John’s books; see TC to JAC, 17 Aug. 1862. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 Feb. 1856.]
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: The book which has pleased you, thro’ its “insane genius and enormous cribbing,” was presented to Mr C by the authorBoth unidentified. and no copy I will be bound to say fell into more thankless hands! I have heard it was not procurable at the bookshops, which is, after all, even more wonderful than that there should be human beings desirous to possess it! But if you or any such distinguished character were to apply to the Author himself; I should think he would be very ready to give you a copy, and would consider himself the party obliged. The copy in Lady Ashburtons hands is however very much at your service, provided Lady A chooses to part with it, and that you will, before entering into possession of it at all, lend it to Mr Arthur RussellArthur Russell (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock, 1857–85; the Carlyles had known him since at least 1852; see 27:385TC to LA, 30 Dec. 1852 (where his b. date is given as 1829). to whom I promised it a month-ago—Mr C “desires to be delivered now and henceforth from all such unadulterated nonsense“—and for me, if there be anything I can part with without a sigh, it is a book of “insane genius.”
Perhaps in the course of ages you will come here and thank me for my generosity
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 16 Feb. MS: NLS 552.120. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: It will be safer not to come tomorrow night, as, unluckily, I am like to be called out.

I have two Letters in the Helden-Staats= &c Leben,—Letters about the Siege of PragSee Works 16:12–22. in ’44,—which I want you to try your hand upon abridging; reducing, say, to the 5th part of their present size (whh will be a useful feat for them and me!): you can get them, if you happen to be here any afternoon, before Sunday come a week; but indeed there is no hurry. I also think of some abridgements from Büsching’s Beyträge,Anton Friedrich Büsching (1724–93), Beyträge zu der Lebensgeschichte denkwürdiger Personen, insonderheit gelehrter Männer (Halle, 1783–89); see 29:335TC to JN, 19 June 1855. which might be useful; but these are in a still more immature state, most of them.

In the Museum, one day, I saw the old German Book of Reformation Portraits:Unidentified. they are dreadfully ugly, one and all, but have a certain air of reality;—only Christian II of DenmarkChristian II (1481–1559), king of Denmark and Norway (1513–23) and of Sweden (1520–23). was of much interest to me; the others I had mostly seen in more reliable form. It was not Horace Walpole’s Book, but old Horatio his Uncle’s.Horatio Walpole (1678–1757), diplomat, who advocated a good understanding with Prussia (1738–40) and then an alliance (1747–48), see ODNB pbd. political pamphlets; brother of Robert Walpole (1676–1745), 1st earl of Orford, who was the father of Horace Walpole (1717–97), 4th earl of Orford, author, letter writer. The book is possibly William Coxe, Memoirs of Horatio, Lord Walpole. … Selected from His Correspondence and Papers, and Connected with the History of the Times, from 1678 to 1757 (1802).

Decker, with his Succession War,Possibly Decker’s book on the Seven Years’ War; see TC to JN, [5 Feb.]. was very elaborate and pretty; but, except a few Portraits (very few, of men and places), seemed to be a work of imagination only.
I find the old Gentleman’s MagazineFounded 1731. (which has Indexes &c, like a human production) very useful to me.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

bibl.person: THE LAWS OF PROPERTY AS THEY AFFECT WOMEN [LOP]

div3.sourceNote: Petition for Reform of the Married Woman’s Property Law Presented to Parliament, 16 Feb. Pbd: Leader, 16 Feb. 148–49; Westminster Review, n.s. 10 (Oct. 1856): 336–38; Lee Holcombe, Wives and Property: Reform of the Married Women’s Property Law in Nineteenth-Century England (Toronto, 1983) 237–38. Text: Leader. JWC’s name was included in the list of signatories on the petition pbd. in the Leader prior to its presentation to Parliament, 14 March. As the preamble in the Leader makes clear, the petition was available for signing at the publishers’ offices of Chapman and Hall, Smith and Elder, Mudie’s Library, W. and E. Cash, and C. Fox. JWC does not mention the petition in her letters (or the Journal). It is included here for its interest as an unusually public act by her; she was presumably encouraged to sign by Jewsbury and by the participation of several other women that she knew. The petition was presented to the House of Lords, 14 March, by Lord Brougham (1778–1868; ODNB), as “from above 2000 of our fellow country-women, of various stations,” and to the House of Commons, also 14 March, by Sir Thomas Erskine Perry (1806–82; ODNB), who was later to lead the debate, 10 June, in favor of reform: “during the Session no less than seventy petitions had been presented complaining of the law as it affected the property of married women. Some of those petitions bore the signatures of the most thoughtful portion of society; the most marked one of the whole, perhaps, was the one which he presented before Easter, which was signed by 3000 women, amongst whom were ladies who had made the present epoch remarkable in the annals of literature” (Hansard, 3d ser., 142 [1856]: 1273). The publication of the petition in the Westminster Review gave the larger figure, “upwards of 3000 signatures” (n.s. 10:338).
div3.head: JWC TO LOP

docBody.p: THE LAWS OF PROPERTY AS THEY AFFECT WOMENThe campaign for changing property laws affecting women had been organized by the Women’s Committee, founded by Barbara Leigh Smith (1827–91; ODNB; known as Leigh Smith Bodichon after her marriage, 1857), a cousin of Blanche Clough and Florence Nightingale; she had pbd. A Brief Summary of the Laws of England Concerning Women (1854) and had been courted by Neuberg, 1855. The committee also included Eliza Fox (1825–95), artist; Mary Howitt (1799–1888; ODNB; see 18:35TC to JRC, 4 May 1844); Anna Brownell Jameson (1794–1860; ODNB; see 10:196TC to ABJ, 12 Oct. 1838); Bessie Rayner Parkes (1829–1923), women’s rights campaigner until her marriage, 1867, to Louis Belloc; and ElizabethElisabeth Jesser Reid, b. Sturch (1789–1866), Unitarian, antislavery activist, philanthropist, and founder of Bedford Coll., 1849. One of the first organized women’s rights groups in Britain, the committee was radical in its outlook. It refused to ally itself with Caroline Norton (1808–77; ODNB; see 8:354TC to JSM, 25 June 1836), already known for her individual campaigns for married women’s rights; see 28:272TC to JN, 15 Sept. 1853. Fearful that their opponents might use Norton’s scandalous reputation to undermine their demand for comprehensive property rights, the Women’s Committee looked for more respectable names to head their petition. See also Pam Hirsch, Barbara Leigh Smith Bodichon (1998).

p.hi: A Petition for which the Signatories of Women are requested.

Sheets of this Petition are lying for Signature at Messrs. Chapman and Hall, 193, Piccadilly; Messrs. Smith and Elder, 65, Cornhill; Mudie’s Library, New Oxford-street; Messrs W. and E. Cash, Publishers, Bishopgate-street, and Mr. C. Fox’s, Paternoster-row.
p.note: It was apparently also available outside of London for signing; for example, the Scotsman in Edinburgh, 14 Feb., noted that a copy lay in their office: “If anything should give weight to this petition, it is the list of names already appended to it.” It also circulated privately; Marian Evans wrote to a friend, 16 Jan.: “Miss Leigh Smith has sent me a copy of a Petition to be presented to Parliament praying that married women may have a legal right to their own earnings, as a counteractive to wife-beating and other evils. I don’t know whether you … will think the object worth attention, but if you do, I will send the paper for your signature. The petition is well and soberly drawn up, and has been signed by Mrs. Gaskell, Harriet Martineau, Mrs. Jameson and the et ceteras. So you will be in good company, if you care about that. I dare say … some other friends of yours will be willing to sign,” (The George Eliot Letters, ed. Gordon S. Haight [New Haven, 1954] 2:225).

p.hi: To the Honourable the House of Commons, in Parliament assembled, The Petition of the Undersigned Women of Great Britain, Married and Single,

docBody.p: Humbly Sheweth,—That the manifold evils occasioned by the present law, by which the property and earnings of the wife are thrown into the absolute power of the husband, become daily more apparent. That the sufferings thereupon ensuing, extend over all classes of society. That it might once have been deemed for the middle and upper ranks, a comparatively theoretical question, but is so no longer, since married women of education are entering on every side the fields of literature and art, in order to increase the family income by such exertions.

That it is usual when a daughter marries in these ranks, to make, if possible some distinct pecuniary provision for her and her children, and to secure the money thus set aside by a cumbrous machinery of Trusteeship, proving that few parents are willing entirely to entrust the welfare of their offspring to the irresponsible power of the husband, to the chances of his character, his wisdom, and his success in a profession.

That another device for the protection of women, who can afford to appeal, exists in the action of the Courts of Equity, which attempt within certain limits to redress the deficiencies of the Law; but that trustees may prove dishonest or unwise in the management of the funds entrusted to their care, and Courts of Equity may fail in adjusting differences which concern the most intimate and delicate relation of life;—that legal devices, patched upon a law which is radically unjust, can only work clumsily, and that here, as in many other departments of justice, a clearance of the ground is the chief thing necessary. That, since this is a truth, which has gradually come to be recognised in regard to protective restrictions upon trade, to titles of property in land, and to the legal machinery for conveying such property from one owner to another, &c., we would hope that before long it will also come to be recognised in matrimonial legislation.
That it is proved by well-known cases of hardship suffered by women of station, and also by professional women earning large incomes by pursuit of the arts, how real is the injury inflicted.

That if these laws often bear heavily upon women protected by the forethought of their relatives, the social training of their husbands, and the refined customs of the rank to which they belong, how much more unequivocal is the injury sustained by women in the lower classes, for whom no such provision can be made by their parents, who possess no means of appeal to expensive legal protection, and in regard to whom the education of the husband and the habits of his associates offer no moral guarantee for tender consideration of a wife.

That whereas it is customary in manufacturing districts to employ women largely in the processes of trade, and as women are also engaged as sempstresses, laundresses, charwomen and in other multifarious occupations which cannot here be enumerated, the question must be recognised by all as of practical importance.

That newspapers constantly detail instances of marital oppression, “wife-beating,” being a new compound noun lately introduced into the English language, and a crime against which English gentlemen have lately enacted stringent regulations.A bill for the “better Prevention and Punishment of Aggravated Assaults upon Women and Children,” applying to England and Wales, had been introduced to Parliament, 10 March 1853, citing several recent cases of men charged with beating their wives. The word “wife-beating” was not used in the bill or debates. The act was passed 14 June 1853. The OED cites “wife-beating tyrant” from Mary Russell Mitford, Our Village: Sketches of Rural Character and Scenery (1830) 4:86 and George Eliot’s use, Jan. 1856 (see n.2).

But that for the robbery of a man of his wife’s hard [won]Omitted in Leader. earnings there is no redress—against the selfishness of a drunken father, who wrings from a mother her children’s daily bread there is no appeal. She may work from morning till night, to see the produce of her labour wrested from her and wasted in a Gin Palace, and such cases are within the knowledge of every one.

That the law, in depriving the mother of all pecuniary resources, deprives her of the power of giving schooling to her children, and in other ways providing for their moral and physical welfare; it obliges her, in short, to leave them to the temptations of the street, so fruitful in juvenile crime.

That there are certain portions of the law of husband and wife which bear unjustly on the husband, as, for instance, that of making him responsible for his wife’s debts contracted before marriage, even although he may have had no fortune with her. Her power also after marriage, of contracting debts in the name of her husband, for which he is responsible, is too unlimited, and often produces much injustice.

That in rendering the husband responsible for the entire maintenance of his family, the law expresses the necessities of an age, when the man was the only money-getting agent; but that since the custom of the country has
greatly changed in this respect the position of the female sex, the law of maintenance no longer meets the whole case. That since modern civilisation, in indefinitely extending the sphere of occupation for women, has in some measure broken down their pecuniary dependence upon men, it is time that legal protection be thrown over the produce of their labour, and that in entering the state of marriage, they no longer pass from freedom into the condition of a slave, all whose earnings belong to his master and not to himself.

That the laws of various foreign countries are in this respect much more just than our own, and afford precedent for a more liberal legislation than prevails in EnglandNorton had made great rhetorical play with the differences between the divorce laws of England and those in Scotland, where divorce was supposedly more accessible to women, in A Letter to the Queen on Lord Chancellor Cranworth’s Marriage and Divorce Bill (1855) 14–33.—and your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will take the foregoing allegations into consideration, and apply such remedy as to its wisdom shall seem fit—

p.title: And your Petitioners will ever pray.

docBody.p: Anna Blackwell; Isa Blagden; Elizabeth Barrett Browning; Sarianna Browning; Mrs. Cowden Clarke; Charlotte Cushman; Amelia B. Edwards; Eliza F. Fox; Mrs. Gaskell; Matilda M. Hays; Mary Howitt; Anna Mary Howitt; Mrs. Jameson; Harriet Martineau; Honble. Julia Maynard; Mary Mohl; Bessie Rayner Parkes; Mrs. Reid; Miss Sturch; Mrs. Carlyle; Miss Jewsbury; Mrs. Lovell; Mrs. Loudon; Miss Leigh Smith.Anna Blackwell, sister of Elizabeth Blackwell (1821–1910; ODNB the first woman to gain a medical degree in the U.S., 1849), author of Poems (1853) and trans. of George Sand, Jacques (1847). Isa Blagden (1816–73), artist, novelist, and poet; one of the Barrett Browning circle in Rome. Sarianna Browning (1814–1903), Robert’s sister, who lived in Camberwell with their father, also Robert (1781–1866), until his death. Mary Victoria Cowden-Clarke (1809–98; ODNB), m. in 1827 Charles (1787–1877; ODNB); she compiled, 1829–41, Complete Concordance to Shakespeare (1844–45); they lived abroad from 1856. Charlotte S. Cushman (1816–76; see 25:112JWC to HW, 4 July 1850), American actor. Amelia Blandford Edwards (1831–92; ODNB), journalist, novelist, later an Egyptologist; her first novel was My Brother’s Wife (1855). Elizabeth Gaskell (1810–65; ODNB; see 24:50JWC to JW, 17 May 1849, and 25TC to IKH, 16 April 1849:314), novelist. Matilda M. Hays (“Max”) (b. 1820), author of Helen Stanley (1846); trans. of George Sand; one of Cushman’s lovers, she had played Juliet to Cushman’s Romeo, 1848; Browning later refused her request for support for a literary pension (18 March 1865; A. Joseph Armstrong, ed., Letters of Robert Browning to Miss Isa Blagden [Waco, 1923] 116). Anna Mary Howitt (1824–84; see 18:35TC to JRC, 4 May 1844), Mary Howitt’s eldest da., artist, author of An Art-Student in Munich (1853). The Hon. Julia Maynard (d. 1868?), 4th youngest da. of Henry Maynard, 6th bart. Mary Mohl, b. Clarke (1793–1883; ODNB), m. 1847, who had a literary salon for many years in Paris; author of Madame Récamier: With a Sketch of the History of Society in France (1862). Mary Sturch, who lived with her sister, Elizabeth Reid, at 21 York Ter., also an antislavery activist, and involved in the founding of Bedford Coll. Maria Anna Lovell (1803–77; ODNB), actor and dramatist. Jane Loudon, b. Webb (1807–58; ODNB), horticultural and misc. writer, including The Ladies’ Companion to the Flower Garden (1841). For the others, see above and the Biog. Notes. The Westminster Review printed the list of names alphabetically. Most of the women were connected through Unitarianism, antislavery and women’s rights campaigns, and artistic pursuits (writing, painting, or acting).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 23 Feb. MS: NLS 552.121. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I am very sorry to be again engaged on Sunday Evg! But the Ashburtons are here, quitting Town next day; and I suppose I must go and take leave. Happily there is no work suffering by your absence: I am in the Battle of Striegau;Also called the battle of Hohenfriedberg, it took place 4 June 1745; see Works 16:119–27. and have all the materials for that about me, if I can make good use of them.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WA, 23 Feb. Addr: Junior Lane / Ballyshannon / Ireland. MS: NLS 3823.123. Pbd: H. Allingham and E. Baumer Williams, eds., Letters to William Allingham (1911) 142–45 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM ALLINGHAM

docBody.p: I like your idea. It is original; and like the notes of the nightingale “touching and strong.”Goethe, Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship; see Works 23:113. I shall bear it in mind for my own use. Now and then I have met with a person “here down”See 17:33JWC to TC, 9 Aug. 1843. (as Mazzini calls it) whom absence did not sweep from my recollection, and to whom, in some dreamy moment I should have liked to say, “I remember you; do you remember me?” But it never occurred to me to do this, tho’ so extremely easy to be done! without having gone thro’ the slow preliminary to a regular friendly correspondence. and to regular friendly correspondences, indeed to regular anything I have a sacred horror of committing myself— This sort of impulsive irregular thing suits me exactly; so I thank you for your letter and answer it with right good will.

What you say of Ruskins bookModern Painters, vol. 3. is excellent. “Claret and buttermilk” till one don’t know which is which! But what could be expected from a man who goes
to sleep with, every night, a different Turner’s picture on a chair opposite his bed “that he may have something beautiful to look at on first opening his eyes of a morning” (so his Mother told me)Margaret Ruskin, b. Cox (1781–1871); presumably during one of the two visits they made to Denmark Hill, summer 1855; see below. Ruskin was Turner’s executor. Mrs RuskinEffie. I suppose was not beautiful enough to open one’s eyes on the first thing; and, hinc illae lachrymae [hence those tears]!Terence, Andria 1.1. you see Millais (I dont know how to spell him) and she have married—you wouldn’t believe me, I have heard of her several times since her marriage, from people who had seen her in ScotlandJohn Everett Millais (1829–96; ODNB) and Effie Gray m. 3 July 1855. They had a month-long honeymoon in Scotland, settling at Annat Lodge, Perth, 6 Aug. 1855.—one said she looked ‘sad’; another that she looked ‘cross’; another that she kept Millais in order; and another that she was “in an interesting situation.”Effie wrote to her father, 29 July, that Millais “diverts me beyond everything,” and that she had not laughed so much since she was ten years old. Millais wrote to a friend that Effie sang every morning and that they were “the happiest couple in the world” (G. H. Fleming, John Everett Millais [1998] 149–50). Their first child was b. 29 May. As for Ruskin; I never saw a man so improved by the loss of his wife!Allingham omits from “Mrs Ruskin” to here. He is amiable and gay, and full of hope and faith in—one doesn’t know exactly what—but of course he does. Twice last summer he drove Mr C and me and Nero out to his place at Denmark hill, and gave us a dinner like what one reads of in the Arabian Nights, and strawberries and cream on the lawn; and was indulgent and considerate for even Nero! and I returned each time more satisfied, that Mrs Ruskin must have been hard to please.See also 30:206–8JWC’s Journal, 30 Oct. 1855. One feels always, one could manage other women’s husbands so much better than they do—and so much better than one manages one’s own husband!

We lived in the same house with Alfred Tennyson lately—at Lord Ashburton’s in Hampshire—and he read Maud and “other poems” aloud to us—and was much made of by all the large party assembled there.See JWC to MW, [10 Jan.]. He seemed strangely excited about Maud—as sensitive to criticisms on it, as if they were imputations on his honour—and all his friends are excited about Maud for him! and an unknown Cambridge gentleman wrote to Mr Carlyle to ask him to be so good as inform him what was his opinion of Maud!!! You may imagine how Mr C would toss that letter into the fire, sending a savage growl after it!

Dear Mr Allingham be a Poet by all means, for you have a real gift that way; but for Gods sake beware of becoming too caring about whether your gift is appreciated by “the million“—of Jack asses. The nightingale dont trouble itself about appreciation—and sings none the worse for that.

I can’t tell you how glad I was that you got back to humdrum work,TC had encouraged Allingham to return to Ireland in 1854, helping him be reinstated as a customs officer; see 29:64–65TC to SSR, 16 April 1854. He was now working in New Ross, Co. Wexford. yielding you visible means and not overworking your nervous system.

I never thanked you for the book of poems you sent me—the custom of this house is to send away the books of poems that come, to the first person one can think of that “cares for that sort of thing” When I tell you that your Day and Night songs, were not sent away; but on the contrary placed in my little private bookcase, in my own room, and still stand there; you will perceive they must have had some peculiar charm for me—either of merit or of affection—or of both together.Allingham had sent the first edn. to JWC in 1854; see 29:35JWC to WA, 1 March 1854; rev. and enlarged as The Music Master, A Love Story, and Two Series of Day and Night Songs (1855).

Mr C says there is nothing of the least moment in the 4 vol edition of his Cromwell that is not in the 3 vol and supplement one—The 4-vol. edn. was the 3d English edn., 1850; the 3-vol. one was the 2d English edn., 1846.

As to the atlases he does not discommend Brewer for he never heard of it before. But he thinks Arrowsmith’s Gen’ Atlas—the best little atlas he ever saw. Also Walkers England is very good, and the Govt map of Ireland (4 pieces) excellent.Possibly Rev. John Sherren Brewer, Elementary Atlas (1854); John Arrowsmith, The London Atlas of Universal Geography (1834), or the 1845 edn., which made use of new surveys of Australia, N. America, and Texas; either John Walker (1759–1830), Walker’s Tour Through England and Wales (1809), or John Walker (1786?–1873) and Charles Walker, Walker’s Map of Railways in England and Wales (1838). The mapping of Ireland was largely taken over by the British govt. from the 1820s with surveys done by the Royal Engineers. The surveyor in Ireland, 1828–46, was Thomas Aiskew Larcom (1801–79; ODNB; see 25:108TC to WA, 29 June 1850). The govt. map is either the map compiled from the surveys of the Board of Ordnance for the railways and other approved documents by J. and C. Walker (1838), the edn. by James Wyld, geographer to the Queen (1839) or J. Arrowsmith, under the authority of the Board of Trade, Skeleton Map of Ireland Having Delineated Therein the Course of Several Projected Railways (1846), pbd. by order of the govt. because of its general interest. And now good by dear Mr Allingham—and as a German friendPerhaps Hedwig or Oskar von Reichenbach. of mine wrote to me from America the other day “a serene mind to you in the new era”!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[TW][TWO], 2 March. MS: Univ. of Texas Lib. inc. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee conjecturally identified as Woolner because of TC’s reference to having sat for him and because of Woolner’s interest in Cromwell. Thomas Woolner (1825–92; ODNB; see TC to TWO, 21 Feb. 1851, and TC to LAI, 12 Aug. 1852), sculptor and poet, member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood. In 1858, Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson that he had visited TC and they had talked a “deal about Oliver Cromwell—for I would some time like to get up a statue” (Amy Woolner, Thomas Woolner, R.A., His Life in Letters [1917] 153). In 1881, he was to carve a large head of Cromwell in stone.
div3.head: TC TO [THOMAS WOOLNER]

docBody.p: Your Letter was delivered me last night at the Athenaeum; the first chance they had had of me there. I go very seldom to that or any other place at present, being extremely busy.

Oliver Cromwell has no squint, stare, or deficiencies of any kind in the eyes of him. One eye (probably the left right?, but I am not sure) is considerably bigger than the other; that is to say, wider open,—habit of looking intently, and rather with one’s right side, for sake of the right hand?— He has no wart on his underlip, nor anywhere but above one eyebrow, near the nose (right side, I think?): a small tuft of a Charles-FirstA short pointed beard. is visible on the underlip, thin moustache on the upper: nothing more, of the mark kind, in that quarter. He is found, on measurement, to have a face bigger than almost any other man’s,—among its various other prominences, this is one.

There are very many false and absurd Portraits of Oliver in circulation: nevertheless the real face of him is capable of being perfectly well known The dead mask of it is to be had in Stucco-shops (a man with an Italian name near Soho-square used to have them);Probably Paul Garbanati, carver and gilder, 31 High St., St. Giles’s, in 1856 Post Office Directory, and 14 Marlebone St. (later Glasshouse St.), Piccadilly, in 1857 Directory, both addresses near Soho Sq. Woolner later acquired a death mask of Cromwell from Garbanati from which he had seven casts taken. He gave one of them to TC in 1870. He also gave TC a memorandum saying why it was a more authentic likeness than other casts and describing the provenance of the mask, saying that “Mr. Garbanati of Glasshouse St.” had bought it in 1853 (MS: Houghton fMS Am 1792 [2]). In 1873, TC gave the cast and the memorandum to Charles Eliot Norton (1827–1908); see Letters of Charles Eliot Norton, ed. Sarah Norton and M. A. DeWolfe Howe (1913) 1:478. In 1881, after TC’s death, Norton gave the mask to Harvard University, “that it may be with those books relating to Cromwell which Mr Carlyle has bequeathed to it with such memorable and affecting words” (MS: Houghton: fMS Am 1792 [3]). a goodish Oil Picture is to be found in the Museum: Cooper “that prince of limners” (as old Anthony Wood, his contemporary, justly calls him) did an elaborate and extremely successful Miniature of Oliver;The “goodish Oil Picture” is possibly the 1654 portrait by Peter Lely (1618–80), now owned by Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery, or one of the portraits by Robert Walker (d. 1658?), although TC told Norton, “[t]he portrait of him by Walker isn’t Cromwell; but the miniature by Cooper has got his face. I had it engraved for my book, but the subtile excellence of the portrait all oozed out in the process” (Letters of Charles Eliot Norton 1:455). Samuel Cooper (1609–72); Anthony À Wood (1632–95), historian. For the engraving of Cromwell from Cooper’s 1656 miniature, see Works 6:frontispiece. The original is in the National Portrait Gallery, London. one or more, which he seems to have copied several times, being now
master of the face: such Coopers, in perfect preservation, still exist in the hands of persons tracing descent to Cromwell;—I know one of undoubted genuineness in a House in Essex:Untraced. TC had been driven by FitzGerald, Aug. 1855, to a “notable mansion” with “a notable Portrait of Oliver,” about 9 mi. from Woodbridge, Suffolk, but 9 mi. would not have taken them into Essex, nor was TC impressed by the portrait; see 30:34TC to JWC, 15 Aug. 1855. what I can believe to be, as it were, the very face of Cromwell, or the nearest we shall ever come to that. Cooper (if one avoid well the spurious “Coopers,” which also exist in plenty) was the man of men to do such a face. There are Medals also by good contemporary hands;Thomas Simon (1623?–65), chief engraver of the Tower Mint, created most of Cromwell’s medals; some are in the National Portrait Gallery, London; see John Cooper, Oliver the First (1999) 12–18. The medal in Swansea is untraced. and I know one Medallion (at Swansea in Wales) which much pleased me.

In all the good Pictures the eyes have a singular wild earnestness, wild silent sorrow you might call it; the mouth and lips are very grand: the face altogether is heroically grim and heroically kind and true (in Cooper especially) to the superlative degree. On the whole I am not acquainted with any grander human countenance, to my thinking.

I fear all this is too late, and that you may have already left Frome.Town 24 mi. SE of Bristol. Woolner had presumably been visiting as he lived at 27 Rutland St., Hampstead Rd., London. But I would not lose a moment in sending you such hurried indications as I could, in case they might still be useful.

I have by no means forgotten the inexhaustibly goodhumoured man, whom I sat to long ago;In 1851; see 26:37TC to TWO, 21 Feb. 1851, and 39TC to JCA, 2 March 1851. whom I have ever since wished well to. Believe me / Yours always sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 5 March. MS: NLS 7197.55. Pbd: Cate 73–74.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
It is certainly a sad “land-change”Cf. Tempest 1.2. these words of the Sea-Hero have suffered in the House of Lords: “This bit of work done, or else my life!” into,
“That peacock’s feather got, or else life lost!”Lord Stanhope introduced a motion to the House of Lords, 4 March, to present an address to the queen for the formation of a British national portrait gallery. During the debate, Stanhope ascribed to Nelson the saying, just before “one of his battles,” “a coronet or Westminster-abbey” (Hansard, 3d ser., 140 [1856]: 1774). In fact, Nelson had said both “Westminster Abbey or victory” (before the battle of Cape St. Vincent) and “Before this time tomorrow I shall have gained a peerage, or Westminster Abbey” (before the battle of the Nile), as TC discovered; see Robert Southey, The Life of Nelson (1813) 1:173 and 219, and TC to JRJRU, 27 March. In support of the motion, Stanhope quoted part of TC to David LaingDL, 3 May 1854, about a Scottish national portrait gallery (Hansard 3d ser., 140 [1856]: 1772); see 29:84–90TC to DL, 3 May 1854. The motion was agreed.— A most sordid platitude; well worthy of being reprobratedThus in MS. and rebuked. If indeed there is any public still left to whom you can appeal, on behalf of the Heroic, against platitudes done in high places and low? Which we are bound to believe there is; tho’, for my share, I often think I do not know where it lives at present,—and in fact have taken shelter by withdrawing out of the dirty welter altogether for the time; and never by any chance look into a Morning Newspaper; but keep well to windward rather, while these big Tumbrils of the Spiritual Night-soil are in passage, poisoning the blessed air of the Heaven-sent new Day of one’s life! Do you, therefore, if you still have faith, pitch into that turpitude; and call a dull-nosed public to look at it: I can have no opportunity upon it. I should not have known what you meant, had not a man happened to call yesterday, with some rumour that there had been a Debate (bless the mark!) about having a National Picture Gallery, whh has long been an aspiration of mine.For TC’s paper proposing a national portrait gallery, sent to Lord Ashburton in 1853, see 28:264TC to RWE, 9 Sept. 1853. “A coronet or Westminster Abbey“: Oh Heavens, Oh Earth!—

You are a happy swift man; I here, slower than the snail or the boring worm and yet human, am very unhappy; buried in endless Giant Mountains of Prussian Pedantry, Prussian Stupidity and Infidelity; seeking a poor prize after all, even if I should attain it! However, I shall perhaps get out one day, and that will be blessedness enough: we must have faith.— Your Book is scattering the astonished cohorts of Chaos into strange agitated groups, I perceive. Which is the natural effect of it, and surely a salutary one by way of preliminary. Go on and prosper.
My wife here has caught cold a week ago, and sits prisoner; otherwise we are in the old way. Ought you not to come and see with your eyes now at last?
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG[AGI], 5 March. Pbd: Gilchrist 47–49; ellipses in original.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Thanks again for your new Gift,An Account of the Ceremony of Investing his Electoral Highness of Brandenburgh with the Order of the Garter, perform’d at Berlin on the 6th of June, 1690, By James Johnston and Gregory King. With the speeches made by Mr. Johnston and Monsieur Fulks (1690).—which I must endeavour again to accept without confusion of face!
