However, we will suppose your impatience no other than just and manful; and taking it so, my deliberate counsel to you is, to sharpen and cultivate your faculties, to train and equip yourself by all possible methods, in modest strenuous silence, as one of the chief conditions of really good progress; and,
on the whole, to aim at getting a better situation by doing, with your whole might, to more and more perfection, the duties of your present one,—which however low, you may depend upon it, can be done with all degrees of excellence, moral, spiritual, practical, and with all degrees of want of excellence in these three respects. You will thus grow, not only to be thought, but to be, a really clever and worthy worker and man; and you need not fear there will be ample need felt of you, in a time with so much work on its hands and so very few to whom it can be entrusted in that high form!—

Too probably you will think this advice very crabbed, and will at once or gradually resolve upon, or drift into, the opposite and too common road: however, I thought good to offer it you (hurried as I am);—and I will wish sincerely you may choose what is right; and so will bid you farewell.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: On 29 April, TC wrote on an envelope addressed to himself (by neither TC nor JWC): “29 April 1856: from my dear little Jeanny:—one of the most generous and neat things I ever saw, figure of ‘horse’ included!—” (MS: NLS 1767.108). There is a note on the envelope (in a later hand) that a drawing was in the envelope when NLS received it, but the drawing contains nothing that obviously represents a “horse,” unless it is “horse” as beast of burden, i.e., the bearer of documents; it is of a respectable manservant with umbrella walking through the rain, with several documents under his arm, and the words in the corner: “Mr James Sheridan Mtt sends more documents to Miss Jewsbury to prove what he had done” (see 74). It is the fifth of a series of six pen and ink sketches by Elizabeth Paulet (1806–79; see 25:34025:biographical note), satirizing a supposed “courtship” of Jewsbury by James Sheridan Muspratt (1821–71; ODNB), chemist and son of James Muspratt (see 18:140JWC to TC, 17 July 1844). They had been done before Dec. 1843, as JWC described them to Helen Welsh then as “a precious batch of caricatures from Mrs Paulet lately professing to be ‘illustrations of Miss Jewsbury’s late matrimonial speculation’—in my life I have seen nothing cleverer. … They were sent at Geraldine’s own request—which was infinitely creditable to her goodnature—for a more abused little tick of a creature than she is represented thro’out never figured in truth or fiction” (see 17:195JWC to HW, 1 Dec. 1843, where the sketches are not identified). Anthony Sterling was also shown them in 1844 (see 18:235JWC to GEJ, 7 Oct. 1844). In the last drawing Muspratt deserts Jewsbury for “a lady who has published a few tracts, & another who has published her own musical composition” (original of 5: NLS 1767.107; originals of 1–4 and 6: privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 2 May. MS: NLS 7197.59. Pbd: Cate 75–77.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
We know not what night you are coming; but hope only it will be soon. I have got your Fourth VolumeOf Modern Painters, pbd. April. (best thanks for such a Gift), and have not yet time to read it except in snatches, but struggle forward towards a freer day
before long. You have an enviable and admirable power of clearing off, in articulate swift piercing utterance, the divine indignation that may be lying in you against the genus charlatan; whereby you can then say, Exoneravi animam meam [I have unburdened my soul], and proceed to new enterprises: it is a very different, and I assure you a much worse case, when said indignation cannot be got cleared off, but lies sticking upon a man, like burning sulphur on the skin of him,—like to drive the poor soul mad till he some how or other do get rid of it! Euge;—and be thankful to Heaven.

It seems the genus charlatan has broken out in strong counter-cry, in some of the Reviews, this month: that also is very well, and indicates to a man that the physic has begun griping,—more power to it.ChorleyH. F. Charley wrote of vol. 4: “This book contains scores of passages … from which we could illustrate the ignorance and knowledge in one,—the combined arrogance and reverence of its writer,—the utter disdain of self-consistency, melancholy in a poet, but culpable in a preacher—and his tremendous assumptions of infallibility in all matters which concern Fate, the Future, and other such grave topics. … [W]e close for the present our dealings with one whose state of mind seems to us grievous, and whose writings are provoking” (Athenaeum 10 May); for his review of vol. 3, see TC to JFJRU, 18 Jan. An unsigned review in the Economist said that the ferocity of Ruskin’s expression had “both lessened and retarded his influence” but that his style was “clear, bold, and racy,” influenced by TC but “without adopting Carlyle’s exaggerated and un-English expression, he has appropriated all that is forcible and vivid in his peculiarities” (1 March; J. L. Bradley, ed., The Critical Heritage [1984] 178–79). Henry Chorley (1808–72; ODNB; see 9:328TC to MAC, 9 Oct. 1837, and 330TC to MAC, 9 Oct. 1837) also reviewed Ruskin in Edinburgh Review and implied that Ruskin was too strongly influenced by TC, writing that he “enters the exhibition-room as an overseer, summoning gallery-loungers to stand and deliver their sympathies,—calling on bad painters to tremble,—and assailing those whom he dislikes with menaces and insults” (103 [April]: 536 and 555). I can well understand how a comfortable R.A. reading these Books of yours, may be driven to exclaim, “I, stiff old stager, cannot alter according to this Ruskin’s precepts: I must either blow my brains out, or convince myself that he is wrong!”Before Modern Painters, Ruskin’s reputation as an uncompromising art critic had grown as a result of his Notes on the Royal Academy’s summer exhibition, begun 1855. In a note on “Beatrice” by Sir Charles Eastlake (1793–1865; ODNB; see 29:93TC to JAC, 9 May 1854), Ruskin said it was an imitation of the Venetians and that Eastlake “ends like all imitators must end, in a rich inheritance of the errors of his original with none of its virtues” and that Beatrice’s face showed “little piety and less wit” (Royal Academy Notes [1855]: 14–15). In March, Eastlake’s wife, Lady Elizabeth (1809–93; ODNB; see 29:93TC to JAC, 9 May 1854), friend of Effie Millais, wrote a fierce, personal attack on Ruskin, accusing him of dogmatism and sophistry, saying that he had “forfeited all title to courtesy,” that he was morally destitute, and that “his writings have all the qualities of premature old age—its coldness, callousness and contraction” (Quarterly Review 98 [March]: 386).— — Nevertheless I bid you be gentle withal; consider that it is a stupid bedrid old world, torpid except at meal-time this long while; and never would, in Art or elsewhere, correspond any way handsomely to the Ideal of its duties. Besides
it makes a dreadful squealing, if you whip it too hard; and does you a mischief in the long run.— This is Pot speaking to Kettle, you will say,—and truly with too much reason. Pot has been longer on the fire (that is all), and regrets his extreme blackness, if he could have helped it by any method!“Pot calling kettle black”; proverbial.

I have a message for you, or indeed two messages. The first is from Lady Ashburton, a very high Lady both extrinsically and intrinsically, who invites you hereby to her Party at Bath House for Wednesday Evg next:I.e., 7 May. the place, as you perhaps know, is in Piccadilly (first gate, to left in Bolton Street there), the hour of rally is probably 10 or after, and the Party I suppose will consist of the usual elements in their highest figure of perfection. Perhaps you will consent to have a look at such a thing in its best perfection, for once? There are very fine Pictures in the House, and many of them, Dürers, MurillosAlbrecht Dürer (1471–1528; see 21:247TC to JCA, 30 June 1847); Bartolomé Esteban Murillo (1617–82), Spanish artist. &c &c: and I certify the Host & Hostess to be themselves highly worth knowing. If you thought of coming, it would be pleasantest if we all went together;—tho’ that, for practical result, is not of the least moment:—we two (unfortunately, I may well call it) are to dine previously that night, somewhere in the Portman Square region;At the Rennies; see 30:248JWC’s Journal, 28 April, and 250JWC’s Journal, 1 May. and wd need to be taken up there (with a good loss of distance to you) if you pleased to like that method of entrance. Either way will do, if indeed you decided to go at all; which I may privately hope or not, but have no business to advise or desire in an audible manner.

The second message is from Lord Ashburton: You made an Address at Manchester lately; which perhaps was printed, separately or at least in the Newspapers:“Address to the Workmen employed on the Oxford Museum,” Oxford, 18 April. It was pbd., Jackson’s Oxford Journal, 26 April. In his address Ruskin echoed TC’s view that “the great mistake of the day was, not distinguishing between work which was calculated to have a permanent and beneficial effect for the good of society, and that which was of a transient nature.” He mentioned speaking to TC “the other day” about the suffering of needlewomen, then cited JWC as saying that the reason for their suffering was that “they could not stitch, and that was the secret of their not getting work; but when they could work in a plain way and a proper way, then they could get employed” (Ruskin’s Works 16:433). his Lordship (an amiable, clear-minded, highminded man,—uniformly high in volitions at least) desires to see a copy of this address; and bids me ask it of you. Comply if you can; even take a little trouble to comply.

And this is all I had at present: sufficient for the day is the evil thereof!Matt. 6:34. You will have to write your determinations on those important points. We are out on Saturday Evg, not otherwise, nor like to be, except as here indicated.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 5 May. MS: NLS 516.26. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:178–79 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I will in spite of fate write you a word today,—you have no idea how many days I have been disappointed in that good purpose, and found my time all up decidedly and more, or some still uglier impossibility. Ah me, Ah me!—

There was not much to be said, at any rate; in the shape of news, next to nothing. We have got round into our usual condition, in spite of the continuance of wintery weather into May,—the harshest frostiest May I ever remember to have witnessed, thus far. Even Jane is fairly on foot again (tho’ still feebler, and making complaint of the north wind): as to me, I am fully as well as before, perhaps a shade better;—and as so much depends on comparison, I hail this degree of bad health as good, after its sort. When clear of dinnering (whh I exert my best industry to be, but am led in once in the fortnight or so, do what I may), there is some capability of work in me again, and I stagger forward with less of despair.

Nay I believe I shall have to get to Press this very Autumn (or sooner) with the First Half of my wretched Book:The first two vols. of Frederick were not pbd. until autumn 1858; there were 6 vols. in all; the printers were Levey, Robson and Franklyn, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane. once fastened to the Printer, I shall have to sort these accumulated rubbish mounds, and cut my way thro’ them better or worse: I see little chance of doing it so well otherwise as on brief compulsion of that kind. Two Volumes cd perhaps be done in that way; then a little pause for other two (or one), whh ends it! At no period of my life have I had such an affair. I have often weakly sunk; and wished I were dead and that job well done. But it will not do except by living,—by standing to it with the “obstinacy of ten mules” as I sometimes say.

There is also going to be another work: an Edition (Cheaper if not exactly “Cheap”) of all my bits of Works; 14 or 15 volumes, 6/ per volume, and very respectable paper & print.Carlyle’s Works, advertised by Chapman & Hall as a “cheap edition” in the Athenaeum, 6 Dec. 1856, and in 1857; there were to be 16 vols. This is very welcome for several reasons,—first of all that it will yield a little fraction of payment again (more than I ever got before perhaps) after so long an interval. For the rest, it will not create much fash to me,—at least not if I can get a right hand, to correct Press, to make Indexes &c, and steadily oversee the thing; which I must be all means endeavour to do.Alexander Gilchrist began and Vernon Lushington continued this work; see Fielding, “Vernon Lushington.”— All this is of the nature of good luck comparatively. The BooksellerEdward Chapman. came down with it the other morning under that character; I
believe he was afraid I might take my new Book past him, whh he would not have liked. A stingy close-fisted kind of fellow; but long-headed, skilful in his craft; and, as far as I know, exact to his bargain. I shall probably continue with him after all,—“keeping an eye upon my partner,” as the Irish gentn did when dancing with a Bear!—

Your sorrows with servants are of a kind growing ever more universal; I often wonder what on Earth is to become of all that! We have to step canny, steady, and get thro’ our part of it as we can.— Jim’s Translation from the Ghost seerHer son James’s translation of Schiller’s Der Geisterseher (Leipzig, 1789). seems spirited and good,—here and there an error in it, mostly produced I shd guess by hurry of transcribing. It is far too close-written, and crowded on the paper, for correcting, or even for reading to eyes like mine, except with spectacles. It is an excellt way of occupying idle time: tell the good youth so, and bid him persevere, persevere. Every bit of useful knowledge he can acquire is worth more than silver or gold to him. A good boy, I do think; and you a lucky mother, as mothers go!

closer.salute: Adieu dear Jean; throw me a word again soon, and I will write.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 5 May. MS: Duke. Pbd: Cate 77.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Our dining-place on Wednesday (day after tomorrow) is “71. Glo’ster Place, Portman Square” (Mr Rennie’s); and it is proposed that you should call for us there at 10 ½,—half past 10;—we will of course come down to you directly; and that will bring us to Bath House in excellt time. To get out of it again, with a carriage,—ille labor hoc opus [that is the labor, this is the challenge] (like the route to a certain other place);Cf. “hoc opus, hic labor est,” Aeneid 6:129, referring to Aeneas’s eventual return from Avernus, the infernal region.—but we can advise about that too, if such is your resolution.

I have little doubt the Oxford Address is what Lord Ashburton meant; but I could not find him yesterday, on trial;—and it was agreed I should take you to him in person on Wednesday evening, and let him tell his own story. Take no trouble therefore about the Address till then,—unless by accident you hear again tomorrow, whh is not likely.
Mr Rennie, “71. Gloucester Place Portman Square, at ½ past 10 Wedy Evg“: that is the essential point;—and I will hope a pleasant meeting.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 6 May. Addr: 193. Strand. MS: Univ. of Calif., Los Angeles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: If you put on your spectacles (outward and inward), and accurately survey these enclosed scratchings,Untraced. you will be able to make out what I mean in regard to that Enterprise.To publish a collected edn.; see TC to JCA, 5 May. So soon as you have made up your mind, pray let me see you again.— We can then also try to settle about the Fredk; whh ought to know soon now what is going to become of it.
I am in the uttermost haste, or I would have written more clearly on the other Paper.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG[AGI], 6 May. MS: Strouse. Pbd: Gilchrist 50–51 inc.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER GILCHRIST

docBody.p: I hope you succeeded with Parker:Either John William Parker or his son, also John William. if you did not, please let me know, that we may think what other quarter to try in.

These are again Capital Books several of them; you surpass all people, of my experience, in the chase of Books!— Riesbeck (or Risbeck) the Traveller is a cleverish fellow by nature, and actually lived in many of the places he describes. An Advocate first or some kind of lawyer, about the Mentz region; he then took to Literature (Passau, Lintz, Vienna), then to Playacting; died (still under 40) as Newspaper Editor at Zürich, where he had translated Coxe &c.Presumably William Coxe, historian (1747–1828); Riesbeck’s translations of his works are untraced. His Book is very like all that.Travels through Germany; see TC to AGAGI, 12 April. Made a great noise in its day; and is still worth reading, especially by me.— The Lettres by main du Maitre, I soon found after you went, are also a decidedly authentic and curious Piece:Published by Fredk’s Younger Brother,August Wilhelm (1722–58), 7th of Friedrich Wilhelm I’s 10 children (see Works 13:16). Lettres secrètes touchant la dernière guerre; De main de maître (Frankfurt, 1771); TC’s copy (Frankfurt, 1772): HCC. striving to vindicate himself agt the fierce condemnation Fredk had passed on his unlucky retreat (from Prag, after the Battle of Kolin) in 1757.— “If justice were done,” said he to the Generals & him, “your heads wd all lie there!” (fiercely pointing to the

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle. Oil painting by Robert Scott Tait, 1854. Carlyle House, Chelsea.

p.hi: Reproduced by permission of the National Trust.

docBody.p: ground), and so turned his Mare’s hips on them, and went off at a canter.See Works 17:203–15. The Brothers, I think, never met more; the younger (great-grandfather of the prest King of Prussia)Friedrich Wilhelm IV. demanded his demission, fell into worse and worse health, and died within 2 years.— — I wonder what Fredk wd have said, to certain gentn returning from the Crimea, with Panmure and “Doub” at the head of them!Fox Maule, 2d Baron Panmure (1801–74; ODNB), politician; sec. at war, 1846–52, and sec. of state for war, 1855–58. Doub for Dowb; referring to ensign Montagu Hamilton Dowbiggin (1832–66), apparently Panmure’s nephew. In the telegram, 1 July 1855, appointing General Sir James Simpson (1792–1868; ODNB) commander of the British troops in the Crimea, Panmure had evidently added, “I recommend Dowbiggin to your notice, should you have a vacancy, and if he is fit.” This was shortened by the telegraphist to “Take care of Dowb.” Sir George de Lacy Evans (1787–1870) raised the matter in parliament, 29 Feb., accusing Panmure of nepotism (see Hansard, 3d ser., 140 [1856]: 1642, 1703, 2109; and Gilchrist 51). Such sight as that he was not condemned to.

I have not yet got into any of the other Pamphlets (except Loudons Life, whh is also good), but I have no doubt they are well worth their money to me. According to bargain, you must now tell me accurately what that same “money” is,—that, for this lot and for all subsequent, was to be the inflexible rule:—I shall then enjoy my conquest, achieved by you; I cannot otherwise. Please buy the Decker too; and I will settle when we next meet.

Do you chance to know anybody that could be depended on for correcting the Press, doing a good Index, and the like services? A good handwriting, some scholarship,—but above all things, exactitude faithfulness, what I call “mother-wit and mother-worth,” wd be indispensable qualities! There is a “Collective Edition” about to be set on foot, for which I should need such a man. Some are vaguely in my eye, nobody decisively; nor have I yet spoken of the matter to anybody.— Considerable sense wd be needed to index (reasonably well) such a set of Books. Only the Cromwell and Fh Revolution have as yet Indexes, but these, I believe (at least the Cromwell’s) are excellent.— —

closer.salute: Hoping soon to see you again,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 May. MS: NLS 525.15. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I send you a poor Oxford & Cambridge Magazine, whh came this morning.The Oxford and Cambridge Magazine, nos. 1–12 (1856), founded by William Morris (1834–96;ODNB) and Edward Coley Burne Jones, later Burne-Jones (1833–98; ODNB), while undergraduates. The May issue was no. 5. For Lushington’s comments on TC, see Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 8–9. If you have anything weighty to do or read, you will not get much good
of that! In fact it is chiefly worth looking at in the prophetic way; as an indication of the sense and nonsense working in the heads of those young fellows, who will be Legislators &c in a few years, and endeavouring to execute what they think. Please spend another penny stamp upon it, and send it on to Jean, who got the former No, and is the natural proprietress of it: I would have sent it on direct, only she got Fraser the other day, and is probably preoccupied with reading for a night or two.

Fuge did get me Seckendorff bound at last,See TC to JAC, 22 [April]. tho’ not till after a fortnight of effort. It is all right now, and will be useful to me far beyond its money value. I was in some fear lest it might be only Half the Book; Varnhagen, whom I was re-reading, cites it once “in four volumes”; but again “in two,” whh latter I perceive is the actually correct way.Several works by Karl August Varnhagen von Ense are cited in Frederick; three are HCC. It is not clear which work TC refers to here. Seckendorf (see TC to JAC, 11 April) was pbd. in 4 vols. We must do without the Journal Sécret,See TC to JAC, 11 April. as without so many things.— Since you heard last, I have got quite a sublime Book on the 7-years War: an elaborated History in the form of Lectures by the “genl Staff Officers” of those parts for instruction of the Cadets in their military Schools: really, I perceive, an excellt work, with Maps, Plans &c in profusion;Possibly Frederick’s Military Instructions Written for the Generals of his Army; being his own Commentaries on his Former Campaigns. Together with Short Instructions for the Use of his Light Troops, trans. by an officer (1762); TC was to be given a copy (HCC) by Gilchrist; see 30:105TC to JN, 5 Nov. 1855.—which is all kept private tho’ in print: on proper application, the King of Prussia permits his AmbassadorCount Albrecht von Bernstorff (1809–73), 9 Carlton House Ter.; Friedrich Wilhelm IV. here to lend it me for what time I like; and on giving my Note of hand to return it when done with, here it is. An honour indeed:—at least I was glad to get the Book after having applied for it; not to be found in a dishonourable position in regard to the affair: this advantage I am sure of, if many of the rest be problematical!

There has also been a magnanimous proposal made by Chapman for a “Collective Edition” of my duds of Writing: I suppose it will go on; monthly volumes, 6/ each, 16 of them, to start abt September;—but I doubt we shall have a good deal of vile higgling about the terms &c before starting.— The Fk too, I think, will have to go on; two volumes of it, as first Half, sent to the Printer before long. The wreck of it is threatening to choke me otherwise; nor does there seem any so likely plan as that of being chased and forced thro’
it.— — I shall be in great want of some exact, acute, faithful person to look over the Proofs &c of “Collective Edition” (whh is to be stereotyped), and also to make a good General Index, which is a job requiring much good sense withal, and a clear steady head and hand. Neuberg I am fallen into a kind of abeyance with, and can, at this time, be either off or on! I am considering what is the real course to follow in such a relation. He has hardly been here at all,—by various accidents and arrangements,—since the night you saw him here so contradictory and piglike!Neuberg had written to TC, 1 May: “The sacred volumes of the State-Paper-Office … have become accessible to me again, and I enclose the ‘recollections’ of a day’s study there.” He called them “recollections” because the superintendent, “a very polite gentleman otherwise,” had enforced the “strict rules of the Department, which are, That no Notes whatsoever, not even the use of a pencil be allowed during the reading. But that for every Note … the permission of the Foreign Office is first to be secured!—Probably what I have ‘recollected’ may serve your purpose.” He had left markers in some passages and asked permission to copy them should TC need more details. He wrote again, 28 May, telling TC that he was sending “Notes and Abstracts from Büsching” and a paper of TC’s, so that TC could “put them all into some ‘pigeon-hole,’ ” and giving his address near Nottingham for the following week. But I suppose I must send again soon.— There is a man Ross,Unidentified. Possibly the same Ross who applied for a post at the London Library; see 27:113TC to AH, 12 May 1852. whom I have been thinking of: a man at regular pay is much the most recommendable;—but I cannot, for the prest, find this one’s address. Him or somebody I shall of course get, by endeavouring a little.

We have the grimmest of Mays here; actual frost, and thickish ice on the pools some mornings: last night it has taken to rain, a bitter east-windish, continuing, drizzle (windows all rattling up here); but we count on Sun following.— Tait has got his ugly smear of me put into the Exhibition, I understand: last year they wd not have it; better have stood by that decision.The Royal Academy exhibition; the portrait (see 84), painted in 1854 (see 29:184TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1854), is in Carlyle House. I have given up even the weekly reading of a Newspaper; hear, as near as I can, nothing of the circumambient Babble and Palaver. A frightful Dinner at the Wedgwoods, last week,—GregProbably William Rathbone Greg (1809–81; ODNB; see 29:283TC to JN, 5 April 1855). He described TC, 1855, as “that raging maniac” (Arbuckle 136). The Wedgwoods lived at 17 Cumberland Ter., Regent’s Park. and other dirty, talking snaffles, to exasperate one’s indigestions. A do coming tonight (I do fear!) in spite of all my struggling,—the Rennies come home from the Antipodes or Falkland Islands; “old friends,” after their sort! We ought to take precaution.
Jane is pretty well;—as I hope you all are at Scotsbrig. You will be coming up again before long? Kindest brotherly regards to my good Jamie, to Isabella & the rest.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [8 May]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Ann Lowe’s letter to TC, 7 May, where she complained that the “fatigue” she had last week had “rendered me so broken that I can scarcely get up stairs” and that they had “not money to pay for assistance.“
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,— This “issue of blood”Matt. 9:20, Mark 5:25, Luke 8:43–44; possibly referring to Ann Lowe’s long annuities. is stopped, is it not? If so, read, and thank Heaven! No answer.—Yours ever
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Thursday morning [8 May 1856]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JLD, 9 May. Pbd: From a Victorian Post-bag, ed. C. Llewelyn Davies (1926) 14. John Llewelyn Davies (1826–1916; ODNB; see 28:biographical note). Davies is noted as fellow of Trinity Coll., Cambridge, and rector of St. Mark’s, Whitechapel, in the ad. for the pamphlet, Times, 2 May. He became rector of Christ Church, Marylebone, 1856–89.
div3.head: TC TO J. LLEWELYN DAVIES

docBody.p: Thanks for your kind remembrance of me. I have looked over your Pamphlet,St. Paul and Modern Thought: Remarks on some of the Views advanced in Professor Jowett’s Commentary on St. John (Cambridge, 1856), in which Davies attacks Benjamin Jowett’s (1817–93; ODNB) The Epistles of St. Paul to the Thessalonians, Galatians, Romans (1855). Davies refers to TC several times, supporting his view that “the deadliest of all heresies” is “that evil is to be tolerated” (31).—with a just satisfaction at least in the chivalrous spirit with which you conduct yourself in battle. Alas, there is much confusion on all hands of us; many seeking (or what they call seeking), few finding: nevertheless, it is true as written, “He that seeketh shall find!”Cf. Matt. 7:8, Luke 11:10.
I have forwarded your Book to a quarter where it will be prized, and may deserve to be made known.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 9 May. Addr: Willesden House / Willesden. MS: NLS 552.123. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Thanks for Preuss’sJohann David Erdmann Preuss (1785–1868; see 29:35829:biographical note), teacher and historian. intelligence: I wish he had told us how he knew that Bonneville was the writer (for it very little resembles anything else I ever saw
of that vain Schrift,German for “writing,” presumably in error for “Schrifter,” writer. who began as a revolutionary Quasi-Mirabeau, and ended, about 30 years ago, as a Dealer in old Books!)—he might, at lowest, have told us when the impious twaddle was first published?Les Matinées de Roi de Prusse (Berlin, 1766). Originally TC thought the writer was Nicolas de Bonneville (1760–1828; see 12:169–79TC to MAC, 19 June 1840), writer, active in revolutionary France. He decided later that it had to be an older de Bonneville, probably Zacharie de Pazzi de Bonneville (1710?–80?); see Works 18:179–84. For Honoré-Gabriel de Riquetti, comte de Mirabeau (1749–91), see 29:16TC to KAVE, 15 Jan. 1854. However, we must be thankful.— Thankful also for RaminFriedrich Ehrenreich Ramin (1710–82), gov. of Berlin; see Works 19:144–45, 184. and the Adjutant (Prince Royal I had already got, out of a Book by Ségur,Louis Philippe, comte de Segur (1753–1830), History of the Principal Events of the Reign of Frederic William II, King of Prussia; and a political picture of Europe, from 1786 to 1796, 3 vols. (1801), trans. from the French original (Paris, 1800). TC’s copy with marginal notes: HCC. whh I have been reading): Ramin is very unlovely,—not unlike his history.

There is great misery and travail here about getting some Beginning for Vol. I actually ready for Printers: I spent yesterday looking over some of these unutterable Paper-masses, a sight to fill one with despair. It seemed to me not one word would suit; and I was not far from clearing my drawers, and delivering the whole abomination to the fire. However, I must have more patience than that (Patience, among other defective virtues), for the thing requires to be done.

Publisher Chapman (not John) proposes, at the same time, a “Collective Edition” such as has been long talked of: 16 voll. 6/ each (handsome volumes, tho’ in smallish type), monthly, to start about September;—there is going to be wanted an accurate hand, and quick eye, to help me then; especially to do a good Index, whh is the work of sound intellect as well as of hand and eye! You I could not think of employing on such services: indeed it grieves me often to think what slavery you have had, without return or result, except an inward one, so to speak! I have my eye vaguely on one or two hireable persons (none altogether ideally fit): if you know, or fall in with, any likely youth (a good hand-writing, sound common sense, and chiefly perfect honesty, as the main requisites), pray let me know.

The other day, a young speculative gentn,Unidentified. much occupied about founding a daily Newspaper on sublimely true principles, very unlike the Times, and who is trying to ascertain if there are any writers discoverable (the Economics &c of the thing being all ready if only the soul could be had),—made me give him your Address, as that of the writer in the Westminster &c. He is a well-disposed (perhaps slightly Germanized) young gentn, and really intends high things: but you are not bound to make any answer, if he come to you, except what will altogether please yourself, and suit your own wishes.

We are to be here this next Sunday Evg: pray come again and see what we are doing. Has Mr TodhunterNeuberg’s neighbor. still a power of buying good horses for weary pedestrian friends? I perceive, a Horse is going to be one of my prime requisites soon.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWD, 9 May. MS: Univ. of Kentucky. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO J. W. DONALDSON

docBody.p: I again want a little bit of Etymology from you,—and solicit patience.

The German all name their great Empress, as you must have noticed, “Maria Theresia,” while the French and English stand steadily by Therèse, Theresa, and know nothing of an i in the case. The Germans even use “Theresius” as a man’s name (as I have observed), and retain the i there too.

Almost beyond doubt I shall have to say “Maria Theresa,”TC duly calls her Maria Theresa; see Frederick. too, if I ever print anything on the Subject:—at the same time, I should like rather to know which of the two parties is right. The real etymology of Theresa, Theresia or Theresius: that would throw decided light upon the question.

I never doubted it must be Greek: some Greek Saint or the like (who perhaps was herself nothing more than a vocable,—as I think they say is Saint Catherine’s Case!);—but with all my dictionaries and guessings I am foiled on that side. Some say Theresa is originally Gothic: I think the Saintess was Gothic-Spanish;The etymology of the name is uncertain.—but I have not even a Bollandus quite at hand.Acta Sanctorum [Lives of the Saints ], begun by a Jesuit, Heribert Rosweyde, taken up by Joannes Bollandus and later Jesuits; see 21:130TC to LHB, 9 Jan. 1847. In short I find it much easier to ask you again.

No hurry in answering; only so soon as you are deliberately sure, please to write one word,—which shall be the answer of the Bacon’s Brass Head to me,See 21:57TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1846. or better than that.

I have not seen you for a long while, and you have had mutations and adventures in the interim. On the whole I suppose you will find CambridgeWhere Donaldson was now living. to be the real soil for such a tree, after all. We have a native country of extreme stupidity, tossed about by dark fierce winds; one has to choose the sheltered places, and the good neighbourhoods.

Sulzer was a man who, like Rousseau, believed in the native goodness of mankind,—professed so to believe. The old Fritz answered him, “Ach mein
lieber Sulzer, Er (He, royal for you) kennt nicht diese verdammte race,—You don’t know that damned brood of creatures!”Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712–78); for J. G. Sulzer’s and Frederick’s exchange, see 29:288TC to AHE, 13 April 1855, and Works 16:337. Which I often remember of the Old Fritz, with a peculiar grin, not of dissent altogether. “Kennt nicht [know nothing],“—Douglas JerroldDouglas William Jerrold (1803–57; ODNB; see 19:209JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1845), author and wit who wrote regularly for Punch. and those other gentn “don’t know”!—

closer.salute: But enough I must babble no more

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir WN[SWN], 12 May. Pbd: H. A. Bruce, ed., Life of General Sir William Napier, K.C.B. (1864) 2:312–14; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:155–58. Text: Shepherd, Carlyle.
div3.head: TC TO SIR WILLIAM NAPIER

docBody.p: I have read with attention, and with many feelings and reflections, your record of Sir C. Napier’s Administration of Scinde. You must permit me to thank you, in the name of Britain at large, for writing such a book; and in my own poor name to acknowledge the great compliment and kindness implied in sending me a copy for myself.See TC to HAB, 12 April.

It is a book which every living Englishman would be the better for reading—for studying diligently till he saw into it, till he recognised and believed the high and tragic phenomenon set forth there! A book which may be called ‘profitable’ in the old Scripture sense; profitable for reproof, for correction and admonition, for great sorrow, yet for ‘building up in righteousness’ too—in heroic, manful endeavour to do well, and not ill, in one’s time and place. One feels it a kind of possession to know that one has had such a fellow-citizen and contemporary in these evil days.

The fine and noble qualities of the man are very recognisable to me; his subtle, piercing intellect turned all to the practical, giving him just insight into men and into things; his inexhaustible adroit contrivances; his fiery valour; sharp promptitude to seize the good moment that will not return. A lynx-eyed, fiery man, with the spirit of an old knight in him; more of a hero than any modern I have seen for a long time.

A singular veracity one finds in him; not in his words alone—which, however, I like much for their fine rough naïveté—but in his actions, judgments, aims; in all that he thinks, and does, and says—which, indeed, I have observed is the root of all greatness or real worth in human creatures, and properly the first (and also the rarest) attribute of what we call genius among men.

The path of such a man through the foul jungle of this world—the struggle
of Heaven’s inspiration against the terrestrial fooleries, cupidities, and cowardices—cannot be other than tragical: but the man does tear out a bit of way for himself too; strives toward the good goal, inflexibly persistent till his long rest come: the man does leave his mark behind him, ineffaceable, beneficent to all good men, maleficent to none: and we must not complain. The British nation of this time, in India or elsewhere— God knows no nation ever had more need of such men, in every region of its affairs! But also perhaps no nation ever had a much worse chance to get hold of them, to recognise and loyally second them, even when they are there.

Anarchic stupidity is wide as the night; victorious wisdom is but as a lamp in it shining here and there. Contrast a Napier even in Scinde with, for example, a Lally at Pondicherry, or on the Place de Grève;Thomas Arthur Lally, baron de Tollendal (1702–66), commander of a French expedition to India in the war with Britain, 1756; he was besieged and forced to surrender at Pondicherry; sent to England as a prisoner; against advice, he returned to face trial in France, where he was imprisoned for two years, then beheaded in the Place de Grève, 9 May 1766. one has to admit that it is the common lot, that it might have been far worse!

There is great talent in this book apart from its subject. The narrative moves on with strong, weighty step, like a marching phalanx, with the gleam of clear steel in it—sheers down the opponent objects and tramples them out of sight in a very potent manner. The writer, it is evident, had in him a lively, glowing image, complete in all its parts, of the transaction to be told; and that is his grand secret of giving the reader so lively a conception of it. I was surprised to find how much I had carried away with me, even of the Hill campaign and of Trukkee itself;Sir Charles Napier had annexed Sind, 1843, but resistance to British rule continued. Truckee was a remote hideout in the Cutchee (Kacchi) Hills, NW Sind, where, after a short siege, rebel hill-men surrendered, 4 March 1845; see History of the Administration of Scinde (1854) 234. though without a map the attempt to understand such a thing seemed to me desperate at first.

closer.salute: With many thanks, and gratified to have made this reflex acquaintance, which, if it should ever chance to become a direct one, might gratify me still more,Sir William Napier wrote to TC from Scinde House, Clapham, 14 May: “Your kind letter has given me great pleasure, not so much by the praise you bestow on my work, tho’ I am not insensible to that portion as coming from so great a master in literature, but for the true and exact view you have taken of my brother’s character. … It would be very agreeable indeed to me to have a personal acquaintance with you, and my hope is to make it in time, but at the moment I have no heart for society for affliction is heavy in my home.” Napier’s married daughter was dying of tuberculosis.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWD, 12 May. MS: Haverford Coll. Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO J. W. DONALDSON

docBody.p: Thanks for Theresia. Please give me the translation of Θηρηςια, and Θηρεςια, or what these words would mean:“Theresia” and its two Greek forms are untraced. Schneider would not tell me when I last inquired.Johann Gottlob Schneider, Griechisch-Deutsches Wörterbuch, 3 vols. (Leipzig, 1819–21); vol. 1, A to K (1819), listed in attic study bookcase, Carlyle’s House 96.

There was another question I forgot: What is the meaning of Grätz, which one finds as an appendage to the names of some German Towns? One old monster of a lexicographer I have translates it by Gradecium (“base-Latin Gradecium”), but does not tell me what “Gradecium,” according even to his notion, may signify.“Graz,” modern spelling of “Grätz,” derives from the Slavonic “gradec,” small town. “Gradecium” is untraced. There is, as you know, besides the Styrian Town Grätz,See Works 14:232. a Königsgrätz (which I believe to be rightly Konigingrätz, according to the old name of it) in Bohemia.Königsgrätz, where Frederick retreated after the siege of Olmutz, 14 July 1758; see Works 17:367.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG[AGI], 12 May. Pbd: Gilchrist 52 inc; ellipses in original.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER GILCHRIST

docBody.p:
… I unluckily know next to nothing about D’Aulnoy,Marie Catherine le Jumel de Barneville de la Motte, countess d’Aulnoy (1650?–1705), author of many books, including Mémoires de la cour d’Espagne (Paris, 1690), Mémoires de la cour d’Angleterre (Paris, 1695), Contes de fées (Paris, 1697) and Les Contes nouveaux ou les fées à la mode (Paris, 1698), trans. by R. R. Planch as Fairy Tales by the Countess d’Aulnoy (1855). Gilchrist was thinking of writing her biography (Gilchrist 52). and fear there is not much that can be known. She has come athwart me early in excerpts from her Spanish, and other Court Delineations, done, I think, in the form of Tours, Mèmoires; in which, tho’ very lively and pleasant, she is said to be extremely indifferent to known and Not-known, and even to True and False. Of her Fairy Productions, again, I hear a highly favourable account from several quarters.— Perhaps in the very latest of the Editions of Moréri’s Dictionary
(1740 or so)Louis Moréri (1643–80), Grand dictionnaire historique, ou le Mélange curieux de l’histoire sacrée et profane, 18th edn., 8 vols. (Paris, 1740) and later edns. Two vols. of the 10th edn., 4 vols. (Amsterdam, 1716–17), and the supplement, 2 vols. in 1 (Paris, 1716) are listed, Carlyle’s House, attic study bookcase. there may be something of her? In that of 1709 there is nothing whatever. BaylePierre Bayle (1647–1706), Dictionaire historique et critique(Rotterdam, 1697); 1st edn. after d’Aulnoy’s death, 3 vols. (Rotterdam, 1715); new and enlarged edn. (Paris, 1820–24). The 5th edn., 4 vols. (Amsterdam, 1740) is listed in Carlyle’s House, attic study bookcase. only quotes her once, and with a slight shake of the head: Biographie UniverselleSee 8:69TC to JFR, 7 March 1835. is utterly meagre.

Perhaps you are right to give up Rogers’s affair;Samuel Rogers (1763–1855; ODNB; see 8:322TC to MAC, 22 March 1836), poet and banker; d. 18 Dec. 1855. Gilchrist may have been thinking of writing his biography. as to the man himself you are certainly right: his poetic sense of beauty was trifling from the first, and had all got contracted into the dilettante and upholsterish form. …For JWC on Rogers, see 24:51JWC to JW, 17 May 1849.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [14 May]. Addr: 58. Lincoln’s Inn Fields. PM: Chelsea, 14 May; 15 May. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written on Ann Lowe to TC, 13 May.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear F.— I began (in my despair) to feel as if this wd never end at all! What on Earth can be the meaning of it? I understood since last thursday, the unfortunate old creatures had got their money, or some Document giving them right to call for it at the given times; and that we (thrice-unfortunate) had heard the last of them.Presumably inspired by the appearance in the Times, 12 May, of the list of subscribers and the total of £305 19s 6d (see TC, CD, and JFTCCDJF to the TimesT, 23 April), she wrote: “We are in great distress—Pray write and let me know when I may expect the benefit of the property—.”— Or is it they that have gone mad?

I am very ill, all this week past; and you are very busy, and not too well:—surely the thing will not torment us both to death, after we are so far thro’ it?— No answer to me. I write a word to the old woman, advising her to inquire of Coutts’s Broker.W. Johnston wrote from Guild of Literature and Art, 16 Lancaster Pl., Strand, 17 May: “I have this day handed over to the Misses Lowes the certificate of the annuity and the balance of the account amounting to £7.10.6. On the envelope, TC wrote: “The Lowes have got their Money! / 17 May 1856.” The final account of expenses connected with the subscription, incl. costs for postage, certificates of baptism, magistrates’ fees, omnibus expenses, advertising costs in the Times and Examiner, and a fee of £4 5s 10d to Johnston, amounted to £13 (FC).— God help us all.— Yours ever,—T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS, 14 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Quot: Ashton 379.
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STERLING

docBody.p: Darling! No letter from you, nor from anyone, was ever welcomer! I was not expecting it; I had taken leave of you, Kate Sterling that day when I opened the door for you, and you walked out into the rain—without an umbrella!On 27 April; see 30:248JWC’s Journal, 27 April.— I had returned to the fireside and taken “a good cry,” because I should see or hear no more of you; till you should reappear from over the horizon as Mrs Ross;After her marriage, 17 May, to Alexander J. Ross; see also 30:252JWC’s Journal, 17 May 1856. JWC had met Alexander Ross about 20 March; see 30:234JWC’s Journal, 20 March 1856. and did I know whether I should like Mrs Ross, as well as I had liked Kate Sterling? It “might be strongly doubted”Coterie speech; from a Maria Edgeworth novel, see 7:35JWC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1833. (as they say in Edinr). Certainly Mrs Ross would not like me as well, or anything like as well, as that dear, romantic, impetuous Kate had done!— And was there not here matter enough for crying?—if one have a tendency to cry.

God bless you Dear! I ought to say all sorts of sensible and encouraging things to you at the present crisis,— —“improve the occasion” in fact—but I can say nothing but just this short and simple prayer—God bless you!

After all I have never found the least good, myself, in what others say to us, either for comfort or edification! One must work out for oneself every lesson of Life, or it is merely like a mathematical proposition learnt by rote—turn the figure upside down, or change the letters, and you stand confounded in your pretensious ignorance! Ah Heaven Yes! Havn’t I, for example been privileged for the last quarter of a century, to hear “the Greatest Thinker of the age” denouncing the sins and shortcomings of the World, the first thing in the morning and the last thing at night, and have I hated and despised the world’s ways a bit the more for all that—? “quite the contrary”; I turn sorry for the poor bad world, and every feeling of mercy and generosity in me is roused to take its part! that is the effect of exhortation on me,—being of a contradictory turn. My dearest, I heard a great deal in praise of your future Husband from a friend of ours Mr Masson the other night. He had been at college along with him.David Masson (1822–1907; ODNB 27:399See 27:biographical note); Masson studied divinity at Edinburgh Univ., 1839–42; Ross was also a student there. Masson decided not to become a churchman during the Disruption, 1843, and Ross joined the Free Church of Scotland. In Memories of London in the ’Forties, Masson wrote about hearing of TC “at secondhand” from “my friend and class-fellow” Ross, who had just returned from Madeira where he had known John Sterling, “whose stay in Madeira for the sake of his health, through the winter of 1837–38, is now one of the memorabilia of the history of that island. … Ross, one of the most genial and sympathetic of men, and with a range of literary tastes and accomplishments and of cultivation by travel much beyond what was then common among Scottish students, had been so fascinated by Sterling that he could not help describing him to me, and repeating to me this and that from Sterling’s conversation—though then little foreseeing the close relationship into which he himself was to be brought with the Sterling family by his marriage, long after Sterling’s death, with one of Sterling’s daughters. Sterling was then a totally new name to me; and I was more interested in what Ross could tell me of Sterling’s talk about his friend Carlyle. At the time … he had known Carlyle about three years; and it would appear that he also, wherever he went, had Carlyle’s name always on his lips” ([Edinburgh, 1908] 12–13). If he make you happy—that is if he help you in making
yourself happy (for I dont believe in any mortal’s power to make another either happy or miserable) I shall like him at first handJulia Sterling wrote to JWC, 25 Dec.: “We find Katy pretty well & of course happy. Mr Ross is so careful of her, & so kind & affectionate to us, in spite of our not meeting him very cordially half way, that I feel ashamed of hankering still after the impossible, & watching for the great or good qualities in him, which by this time I ought to know, there is no chance of ever finding. If only she never makes the discovery that he is a weak poor creature, we must be thankful for his making her so happy” (MS: NLS 1774.94).— If he dont—! just mention to him, casually, that I have two daggers—and the spirit of a Charlotte Corday, or Clocking HenMarie-Anne-Charlotte Corday D’Armont (1768–93), who stabbed to death the revolutionary Jean-Paul Marat (1743–93). A “clocking hen“: a brooding or sitting hen, a woman ready to defend her offspring. where you are in the case.

I met Mr MauriceF. D. Maurice had become the guardian of the Sterling das., Oct. 1853; see 28:318JWC to KS, 19 Nov. 1853. last Wednesday night at a huge Soirée at Bath House.On 7 May; see 30:250JWC’s Journal, 7 May. He looked to me white and lean—not fit to be there,—unless to denounce us all as a pack of idlers and fools! which he did not do; while I staid.— Pity!—

We took with us to that party, at Lady A’s request, Mr Ruskin! And considering how people have stared at that man—ever since he had the happiness to be divorced by his wife, I displayed, I think, a certain force of mind in taking his arm to go in, instead of Mr Carlyle’s and getting myself announced “Mrs Carlyle and Mr Ruskin”! How horribly ill bred people are,—as a general rule!

I have had no news either from or of the Colonel since I saw you—that reminds me of Mrs Tierny;Kate’s uncle, Anthony Sterling, who had apparently transferred his affection in Oct. 1954 from JWC to “Miss Farrer,” i.e., Mary, before her marriage; see 29:194JWC to MR, 7 Nov. 1854. She and her idiot-husbandMary had m., Jan. 1855, Matthew Edward Tierney; see also 30:261JWC’s Journal, 30 June. have been hanging—like ravens—over the deathbed of Sir Edward Tierny the Husbands fatherSir Edward Tierney (1780–1856), 2d bart., crown solicitor, NW circuit of Ireland; wealthy landowner in Co. Cork who m., 1812, Anna Maria, b. Jones, a rich heiress. In 1841 he inherited the estates of Henry Frederick J. J. Perceval (1796–1841), 5th earl of Egmont and, on the death of his brother, Sir Matthew John Tierney (1776–1844), 1st bart., he inherited the title and £30,000 per year. He d., 4 June. His son, Matthew Edward, became 3d bart.; his da. Harriet Mary’s husband, Sir Lionel Darrell, inherited the Egmont estates.—and they are now in the agonies of “waiting for the opening of the
Will.” Ann FarrerAnnie, Mary Tierney’s younger sister. is rushing about telling all her friends that “the old man” had called Mary “My dear Child” and “added in a whisper you will find I have not forgotten you.”

I really should take a malicious pleasure (I fear) in hearing that the remembrance had amounted to fifty pounds for a mourning ring, instead of the twelve thousand a year they hope for— Oh my dear it is the most hopeless symptom of your uncle that I know of—his partiality for these people before all his oldest friends and own flesh and blood—they are such worldly minded, trashy people!

closer.salute: Darling Kate I clasp you to my heart with the warmest truest kisses

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 16 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:222 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 446–47.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: This morning Ruskin, from Dover, sent me the enclosed Note, with an old Newspaper from which I have cut out what was of use to you,—Ruskin’s speech at Oxford to his assembled mechanics.See TC to JRJRU, 2 May. I have not read it, being extremely busy all morning: please do not burn it till I come; perhaps tomorrow or next day (if the Fates are so beneficent) I may find a chance of looking into it. Ruskin I have found in all things to mean well, and aim high with the very highest; but he strikes me always as infinitely too hopeful of men and things,—in fact as having soared aloft out of all contact with rugged facts; which class of objects accordingly he contemplates, as with outspread level wings, very much at his ease, far up in the azure aether.— — It is certain, however, he does teach various working young men to draw, and has a boundless zeal to continue teaching more and more. His Fourth volumeModern Painters. (whh I have not time to read) is full of the finest “eloquence,” Swiss descriptions &c,—the like of whh I have hardly ever seen;—but tending nowhither, except towards the impracticable, the impossible, so far as I could surmise. It is one of the strangest Books, for gift and want of gift, I have ever met with. The man himself I find exceedingly amiable, in spite of all that is said. But he flies out like a soda-water bottle, gets into the eyes of various people (being incautiously drawn), and these of course complain dreadfully!

I do design for Addiscombe before you get away: If the weather pleased to take up, it might be tomorrow,—if I had a horse or hippogriff, why not this very night!—but I have only bad feet and railways, and dejected heart (unwell below par): unless it be really bright, I do not calculate steadily on tomorrow. But we shall see, we shall see. On Sunday I come at any rate;—and tell My Lady I compute, as to Saturday, that if I be not there, at six, I have no right to dinner.

closer.salute: And so I remain, with many aspirations,—recommending myself to your prayers

docBody.name: T. Carlyle—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LA], 20 Aug. [May]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated in May by TC’s one-day visit to Addiscombe and Julia Winton’s visit to JWC, 18 May; see JWC’s Journal, 18 May.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Well, I hope you are getting better, dear Lady, and meaning to come home to us soon? This is a day to amend you of itself.

You were very beautiful, in spite of your cold and your chagrins:—I perceive clearly you will continue beautiful so long as I live to judge you; this I think certain, and this should be enough to me on that head.

All was so beautiful, in spite of the rains and winds; and my Bedroom—Ach Gott! I reminded myself of a banished soul (Satan without the devilry) taking a walk thro’ Paradise:—and yet that was but a sickly thought. The Paradise still in many respects belongs to us all; and all of us too (the beautifullest as the ugliest) get our share of Purgatory, each according to his softness of nerve.— Be not too sad; be serious if you like: that it well becomes all of us to be. And hope, hope; we will never quit hope!

That day I was absent Jane had some Honourable extremely fascinating Welsh Lady (whom she has fallen in love with)Julia Cecilia De Winton, b. Collinson (1812–78); see 30:250JWC’s Journal, 1 May. to lunch with her: honble Lady looking up saw your Picture (it now hangs downstairs, on one side of the mantlepiece, I on the other), honable Lady said, “There is a beautiful woman: who is that?” They told her; she then said: “And he yonder, is that her Husband?” They smiled. “Rather hers than mine!” added this good judge of mankind and womankind,—did not like the cut of that second Portrait;Possibly the lithograph of Lady Ashburton by Francis Holl (see 30:150TC to EMA, 29 Dec. 1855) and a lithograph of TC from the daguerrotype, 1848, listed by Helen Allingham in 1881 as on the west wall of the ground-floor front dining room; see Carlyle’s House 55. The lithograph of Lady Ashburton was sold at Sotheby’s, 1932 (lot 223). whh indeed is very bad. (n.b. she is a Welshwoman this; six feet 2 in stature, and
has great possessions, it wd seem, spiritual and other. Her name I do not remember, nor intend to;—n.b. further say nothing of this!)

I got perceptible benefit from my Expedition; from the furious walk to and from, as from other things, tho’ it was rather rough to do. The benevolent GeorgePresumably an Ashburton manservant. insisted on giving me a cup of tea. I slept only about 2 hours;—shd have been off soon after 4, had my shoes been in the room. Better not.
Here has a Card just come, directed “Brompton” (probably by Rous)Dr. James Rouse. : invites me to dinner for the 4th of June;—surely, yes.

And here likewise has the ill-fated ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley. been (the first time these two months); all the time I have been writing, he sits on thorns (well-deserved) down on the ground floor.— I will try tomorrow, and perhaps find you. Adieu, best Lady.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 [24?] May. MS: NLS 516.27. Hitherto unpbd. TC either writes on Sat., 24 May, misdating 25 May, as he refers in the letter to “Tomorrow” being “Whitsunday in your region”; or 25 is correct, TC using “Whitsunday” to mean a term day; see note 1.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here is a Note (or long Letter rather, if I were not in such a hurry!) just come from Alick; and, lest I fail later in the afternoon, I will begin the day with packing that up for you,—to go on to Jean &c after you have done with it.

The temperature here has grown “perfectly delightful” (as temperature), and the weather I really believe to be propitious in a high degree, as well as pleasant. Lively west winds; bursts of brief sunshine, and a great deal of good rain.— Tomorrow, I think, is Whitsunday in your region; a day that brings many recollections back!Possibly the Scottish term day when rent is due rather than a literal Sunday; TC is probably thinking of his father taking him to Annan Academy for the first time “on Whitsunday morning, 1806” (Reminiscences, 34); it seems more likely that this would have happened on a Monday than a Sunday.—

Nothing is altered here, or nothing to speak of,—except that poor Jane has caught a bad cold again, and did not come down to breakfast this morning, whh is a sign of much suffering on her part. I hope nevertheless it will be off again in a day or two.— — I am busy, busy; but utterly lamed (9 days out of 10) by an overclouded state of nerves,—by the miserable state of liver, in fact! Often, such is the nature of my employt, I cannot get on at all on these terms;
or find I could do more work in an hour, with spirits clear, than I can manage in a week with liver as it is! I am on search for a horse again, at least making some inquiry: I absolutely must attempt some improvement of my health before we begin printing: nothing is so necessary.

SeckendorfSee TC to JAC, 11 Feb.11 April. does contain 4 volumes;—the unfortunate mortal finished the military Histy in 2 volumes 1792 (which I have); and then did 2 others (1794) upon—the political do? Hoping that might be the case, and seeing a 4-vol. Copy cheap at Leipzig, I have ordered it. Yours too in the me[an]while is fairly a prize to me; and even with the 4 voll. copy I shall know how to dispose of it.

Letter from Emerson (after above a year),6 May; he had last written 17 April 1855. which you shall see, when we have got settled about the message or request in it. Request to call on some Yankee Lady of distinction;Anna Hazard Barker Ward (b. 1813), m. 1840, Samuel Gray Ward (1817–1917; see 13:314–15TC to RWE, 6 Dec. 1841, and 25:279TC to RWE, 14 Nov. 1850); a friend of Margaret Fuller Ossoli (see 25:33925:biographical note), who introduced her to Emerson, 1839. In his letter to TC, 6 May, Emerson called her “one of nature’s ladies,” and in his letter of introduction to JWC, 5 May, he called her “the most beloved & valued of all American women.” whose Address is not yet discovered.—Excellt news too of the old (down-broken) American Bond:Presumably TC’s Illinois bond; see 29:21TC to CBU, 17 Jan. 1854. it is now on its feet again,—worth £400 as I understand, and professes to pay 7 per cent! Money goes a mad road in this time.

People are very grumbly about an “Illumination” that is to be forced upon them; kindles itself on Thursday night,—under pain of broken glass, laugh, you!In celebration of peace on 29 May; see also 30:252–54JWC’s Journal, 18 May. The Times Plate Glass Assurance Co. had offered to insure all glass windows in “all Ordinary” houses (Times, 29 May); the Examiner reported: “In addition to the extensive preparations now in progress for illuminating the club houses and theatres, workmen have been engaged in fitting gas apparatus around the Great Western Hotel at Paddington. There will be fourteen upright branches to supply upward of 40,000 jets, forming numerous appropriate devices. The illuminations at the British Museum are intended to be on a scale of splendour rarely surpassed. Besides the innumerable jets of light around the railings, the architectual front of the building will be illuminated with gas. The preparations at Somerset house, the Ordnance office, Pallmall, the War department, Admiralty, Horse Guards, and other public offices, are on a most extensive and magnificent scale. It is stated that Buckingham and St James’s Palaces are to be illuminated. In the City great activity prevails, and some hundred of workmen are employed in erecting gas fittings at the Bank of England, the Post office, the Guildhall, Mansion house, East India house, Custom house” (24 May). See 102.—Adieu dear Brother. My kind love and remembrance to Jamie & the rest. Your affecte
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AJS, 25 May. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO A. J. SCOTT

docBody.p: I am very sorry I can be of no help in this matter. Two Candidates have already applied to me; and I have undertaken to say nothing whatever;—which indeed was my only clear course in regard to such an “Art” as that of Logic.Scott was applying for the chair of logic at Edinburgh Univ.; for the other candidates, see TC to AJS, 5 Aug.; which others had applied to TC is not known.

I adhere to what I wrote long since about you,—believing that it was my true opinion then, tho’ I have quite forgotten the terms of it;—but on this subject I must not write.TC had written a reference in 1848 for Scott for the chair of English literature, University Coll., London (see 23:115–16TC to CUCL, 21 Sept. 1848), and wrote another in 1850 for Owen’s Coll., Manchester, of which Scott became the first principal, 1851–57; see 25:78TC to TOCM, 1 May 1850. Scott’s 1850 testimonials had included one from Sir William Hamilton, whose chair of logic was now vacant.
What my wishes are, it is of no use stating. I believe, whatever I may think of the “Art” in question, you surely would do more good in treating it than either of the Two I allude to.

In great haste (not to lose a post)On 27 May, Scott forwarded to Edinburgh his previous 1848 and 1850 testimonials, including those from Maurice, TC, and John Carlyle. For this application, Scott’s references were to include letters from Thomas Erskine, Maurice (as chaplain of Lincoln’s Inn), Rev. Robert Story of Roseneath (see 19:163JWC to TC, 21 Aug. 1845), James Mackenzie (see 27:4TC to TE, 5 Jan. 1852), and the trustees of Owen’s College. See Testimonials to Alexander J. Scott, M.A. Principal of, and Professor of Logic and Mental Philosophy in, the Owens College, Manchester … Candidate for the Chair of Logic and Metaphysics (Edinburgh, 1856).

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Alan Ker wrote, 10 May, from the West Indies: “Do you ever hear of the Scotts? I am afraid the Manchester scheme is not answering, the people there rather taking offence that Mr Scott is not more regular at church. I should not wonder if he had to shut up shop altogether soon. It made me quite melancholy to hear of his want of success. No man I know has found life a painfuller struggle than he has.”

figure.p: “The Fireworks in the Green-Park: The Grand Finale.” The Peace Celebrations.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB[CBU], 28 May. Pbd: G. L. Prentiss, The Union Theological Seminary … with a Sketch of the Life and Public Services of Charles Butler (Asbury Park, N.J., 1899) 518–20; L. E. Kimball, “Thomas Carlyle and Charles Butler of Wall Street,” Essays and Studies in Honor of Carleton Brown (New York, 1940) 285; both wrongly dated the letter in 1854. Text: Prentiss. Date confirmed by CB to TC, 4 Aug.: “I had the pleasure to receive your letter of the 28th”; it arrived during his son Abraham Ogden’s final illness; he d. 6 June, aged 24.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p: It must be at once admitted, and ought to be always gratefully remembered, you have stood a real father to that poor down-broken bond; and have set it up triumphantly, with victorious kindness, on such a footing as it never had before! I think (so far as vague recollection serves), it bears now almost the value, and yields about twice the interest that was originally attached to it, which is a result valuable to me, in more ways than one. The money is worth something in this ever-hungry world; and as to the transaction which the money now comes from, that is one with a value in it higher, probably, than any money. I may long recollect that pleasant brief evening, and the chivalrous procedure that has arisen out of it.Nov. 1853; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853.

By all means, leave the document where it is, if you will still be so kind as to trouble yourself with the keeping of it.TC had sent a copy of the bond, Jan. 1854; see 29:21TC to CBU, 17 Jan. 1854. If you continue to think the investment safe, I may send you some more in the course of years; the interest, in August or any time, will find uses for itself here.Butler enclosed $70 with his letter, 4 Aug., due “for 6 months” on the bonds “of 1000$ each of the Chicago St. Paul and Fond du Lac Railroad Company which I hold as your agent. If you have a little more money to spare I can place it for you more securely so as to give you about 10%.” And so, with many thanks, let the matter lie arranged.

We are in our usual state here, little different from what you saw, except that I am dreadfully overwhelmed this long while with an ill-fated Prussian enterprise in the Book way, the ugliest I ever undertook, and the most thankless and hopeless, in which, except the unwillingness to be flatly beaten in one’s old days, there is no adequate motive to persevere. This is really a sore job, and I have often fallen nearly desperate upon it. One needs “the obstinacy of ten mules,” as I sometimes say, “in this world.” However, I now do begin, in cheerful moments, to see promises of daylight here and there through the abominable black dust-whirlwind where my dwelling has so long been; and expect to get out of it alive after all, doing a bad Book, the best I can, since a good one is not possible in the case.

figure.p: Charles Butler by Samuel Laurence, 1854. Reproduced from Francis Hovey Stoddard,

p.hi: The Life and Letters of Charles Butler

docBody.p: Of Miss B.,Delia Bacon. I am sorry to report that I know absolutely nothing for many months past, perhaps above a year, when she made her last visit here, and promised to come back soon, but never came. She lives about four miles from us (in a street leading off Hyde Park Gardens, toward the Paddington region, at least there she did live, when I called long since and found her gone out).She had moved to 12 Spring St., Sussex Gardens, near Hyde Park Gardens, Dec. 1854. The last confirmed contact was TC’s letter to her, 7 June 1855, inviting her to call (29:328–29TC to DB, 7 June 1855). I am so held to the grinding-stone, I never, by any chance, get away to such distances, and indeed, hardly make visits at all, this long while. I have often asked myself, and ask all American friends, what poor Miss B. is about? but nobody knew her, nobody can tell. Her very address I have now lost; could find the place, I think, from the physiognomy of the street, were I there in person, and from some recollections of “twelve” as being the number of the house. Poor lady! I fear she is in a very abstruse condition; engaged in an enterprise which is totally without rational basis, and getting more and more exasperated that she does not (as she cannot by possibility) succeed in it.

LaurenceSamuel Laurence, who was living with the Butlers in the U.S.; JWC had written notes of introduction for him; see 29:21TC to CBU, 17 Jan. 1854. need not write to me ’till his demon fairly bids him; I am satisfied to hear of his prospering so among you; for which, I doubt not, the good, meritorious man is thankful. Such “hospitality“—I have often thought of it with loyal wonder; it is like the hospitality of the heroic ages, and rebukes common mankind of our day!

My wife joins with me in kind regards to Miss Lynch (among others of the Chelsea party that evening) whom I very well remember, and still like. My notion is the Sardinian professor may have done an extremely wise thing, in staying where he was on those terms.Presumably referring to the marriage, 1855, of Anne Charlotte Lynch (1815–91; see 28:317JWC to LA, 19 Nov. 1853), New York poet, to Vincenzo Botta (1819–94), prof. of Italian, Univ. of the City of New York. He had been a member of the Sardinian parliament, 1849, and prof. of philosophy, Turin. He travelled to the U.S., 1853, to study the public school system, then settled in New York City, becoming a naturalized citizen. Easily go farther and fare worse.

What a narrow providential miss of the uttermost calamity was that of you and yours.At the end of a year-long tour of Europe in 1854, Eliza Butler booked a passage back to the U.S. for herself and her three children, on the British mail steamer the Arctic. At the last minute she canceled the booking, traveling on a later steamer. During the crossing that the Butlers should have taken, the Arctic sank off the coast of Newfoundland, 27 Sept. 1854. Of 233 passengers and 135 crew, only 31 crew and 14 passengers survived (Annals 417). On the Butlers’ arrival in New York on a later steamer, they were met by Charles Butler; their youngest child Anna fell into the harbor; her father jumped in to save her, and both were almost drowned (Francis Hovey Stoddard, The Life and Letters of Charles Butler [1903] 288–89).

We do well to recognise such things as mercies of a Special Power that has pity on us. Great pity withal is shown us in this universe, where so much rage and cruelty also are—the soil of it only getting arable by little and little. Accept our united regards. I remain always,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady D[LD], 3 June. MS: NLS 7197.61. Hitherto unpbd. Lady Henrietta Dillon, b. Browne (1798?–1862; see JWC’s Journal, 29 April), m., 1807, at Castle McGarrett, Co. Mayo, Henry Augustus Dillon-Lee (1777–1832), 13th viscount Dillon; their da. was Lady Stanley.
div3.head: TC TO LADY DILLON

docBody.p: I am very happy to find that the greatest of the Marshals Browne is certainly your kinsman: he was a person of much talent, worth, and distinction in his day; and gets a new hold upon me by his genealogy now.Lady Dillon’s letter, [31 May], enclosed letters from her nephew, Richard Kirwan, and Mrs. Browne of Moyne: “I think Ulyses Maxamilian is your Marshall—& if he was son to the first mentioned Coll. Browne—no doubt was of my family the Caslle McGarret or McGerald.” Richard Kirwan was presumably related to Richard Kirwan (1733–1812), chemist.

Maximilian Ulyssess Browne (born at Basel 1705, died at Prag 1757),“Ulyssess“: thus in MS. Maximilian Ulysses Browne (1705–57), officer with the Austrian army who d. at the siege of Prague; he may have been b. in Limerick; see marquis of Ruvigny and Raineval, Jacobite Peerage (Edinburgh, 1904). Fieldmarshall Reichsgraf (Count of the Empire) &c, and distinguished by his proved talents and fine character in a still higher degree: he (as Mr Kirwan’s friend supposes)Richard Kirwan’s friend is unidentified. is certainly the man I had in view. Of whom I have found a great many traces in my Austrian Books;—but will at present only mention the following, and with a practical purpose:

His Father and his uncle (says one of my Books), who were called respectively ‘Ulysses Browne and George Brown,George Browne of Camus (d. 1729), col., lieut. gen., and counselor of war, was the older of the two; Ulysses Browne (1659–1731), gen. in the imperial service and commandant; in 1716, they were both created count and baron of the Holy Roman Empire, for military services, by Emperor Charles VI (1685–1740); see also Works 15:13, 17–18. of an ancient Catholic family in Ireland, quitted that country along with King James II in 1690’ (Battle of the Boyne being lost),In Ireland, 1690, when the Protestant king William III (William of Orange; 1650–1702) defeated the Roman Catholic former king, James VII and II (1633–1701), who had been forced to abdicate, 1688, and was trying to win back his throne. ‘and resolved to take service with the Emperor,’—who at that time was Kaiser Leopold ILeopold I (1640–1705), Holy Roman emperor. (much hunted by the Turks &c, but not
just then at War with Louis XIV);—Ulysses Browne’s age was then 34 ‘(born 1656)[’]; George’s age I nowhere find. They both rose to rank in the Army, and in the State: Counts, both of them; and George to be Feldzeugmeister Genl (“Master-of-the-Ordinance” Genl, an Austrian Title difft from ours); Ulysses to be Fieldmarshall (died, I think in 1731,—George a year or two earlier). George had no children. Ulysses when still only a Coll of Horse, ‘Married 24 jany 1699 an Irish Lady, Anna Fitzgerald,Annabella, b. Fitzgerald (1677?–1747?), heiress of James of Knockamy, Limerick. of the noble family of Desmond,’ and she, ‘who lived till 1747,’ brought him Maximilian Ulysses, and perhaps other children.Maximilian Ulysses was their only child. The good old Lady must have been much gratified with the famed actions her son had achieved before that time: Italian War, Turk War, War of Silesia (1740) &c &c

If Mr DaltonProbably John D’Alton (1792–1867; ODNB), Irish historian, genealogist, and biographer. or any charitable person could tell me beyond dispute, who these two young Brownes that went out of Ireland in 1690 with King James were,—whose sons,They were the sons of the George Browne who had drowned in a shipwreck on an expedition against Spain, and Mary, b. Rowe, of Hacketstown, Co. Waterford (Christopher Duffy, The Wild Goose and the Eagle [1964] 1). where born, or if doing anything, what, prior to the Boyne disaster,—it would be a real favour of its sort.

There is another really distinguished Marshal Brown[e,] ‘George, born in Ireland 1698,’ Catholic too, who went abroad accordingly, got into the Russian service; and was for 30 many years a highly esteemed ‘Governor of Livonia,’ after his feats of war were concluded: he did not die till 1792,—only 6 from 100! I know not what sort of cousin he might be to the others.He m. 1740, Helene Marthe, 4th da. of Count Peter Lacy. He was related to and possibly first cousin of Maximilian Ulysses Browne (Duffy, Wild Goose 87).
Other Austrian Irishmen of whom I could like extremely well to know are:

‘Lascy’ (Lacy, two Lacys, Father & son,Count Peter Lacy (1678–1751), Russian field marshal, and his youngest son, Franz Moritz Lacy (1725–1801); in 1737 Franz was sent by his father to study in Austria under Maximilian Ulysses Browne (Duffy, Wild Goose 87); he became a field marshal and fought against Frederick in the Austrian army; see also 30:123TC to AGI, 28 Nov. 1855 and Works 15:18. the first a Russian; son a very high Austrian ultimately, a decidedly superior man): ‘Odonnell,’ Genl of Horse,Probably General Karl O’Donnell (1715?–1771); see Duffy, Wild Goose 124, 147, 215; and Works 18:126. often fighting under Maxn Uls Browne: ‘Macguire,’Probably Johann Sigismund Macguire, Austrian gen., gov. of Dresden (see Duffy, Wild Goose 117; and Works 18:108–10, 235–41). who defended Dresden against Frederick: &c &c.—But I must wait to see what comes of Maxn Ulysses in Mr Dalton’s hands, before embarking upon other adventures!
I surely think I once saw Mr Kirwan, at Dublin; did not know him for your kinsman.— I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRI], [7 June]. Pbd: Cat. of autographs from Henry Sotheran & Co. (1923) 43 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:229 as if to Sir John Richardson (1787–1865; ODNB; see TC to JCA, 19 April 1843). Addressee is John Richardson (1780–1864; ODNB; see TC to JAC, 17 Jan. 1847), parliamentary solicitor, with whom the Carlyles dined, 19 June; see JWC’s Journal, 19 June 1856. Letter dated by Wilson.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RICHARDSON

docBody.p: It is needless to say what a wretchedly dyspeptic soul I am, bewildered too, and indeed quite confiscated, and buried among historical marine stores, and in fact called upon by the voice of reason to eschew and refuse all manner of Dinners! The plain fact nevertheless is, we mean to come upon your summons. The voice of reason says one thing; and that of Richardson, saying another, is stronger.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ET[ETW], [13 June]. MS: Houghton b45M-98 (90i). Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s return from Addiscombe, 11 June, and Ellen Twisleton’s last visit, 19 June, to JWC before her departure “for this season”; see JWC’s Journal, 18 June, and JWC’s Journal, 19 June 1856.
div3.head: JWC TO ELLEN TWISLETON

docBody.p: Darling! That last was the most provoking miss of all! We had just returned from Addiscombe, where we had been since the previous Saturday, and when you came I was close at hand; at Geraldine Jewsbury’s in the next street! I had run over to give her some commissions before retiring myself from public life, into my fourposted red bed! I had come home with such a faceache and such a sorethroat! instead of those charming results always promised one from “change of air.”

All yesterday I was too ill to write you even a bit of a note—While at Addiscombe I dreamed about you one night—a wretched dream—that you were sitting as white as a sheet, slowly weeping, and refusing to be comforted; because Mr Twistleton and you were to be “sparated”!!Thus in MS.—for political reasons; I partly believed; but I could not at all make it out, and knew only that you were miserable and he was misereable, and Miss DwightHer sister, Elisabeth Dwight. and I were
